questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 1-year history of low back pain that is worse at night and improves with exercise. Family history is significant for an inflammatory spinal condition in his father. Laboratory tests reveal HLA-B27 positivity, ESR of 55 mm/hr, and negative ANA and RF. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the sacroiliac joints bilaterally and at the right Achilles tendon insertion site. No joint swelling or rashes are present. Which of the following additional findings would be most suggestive of the underlying condition?

choices.text: Increased range of motion of the spine
Increased lateral curvature and rotation of the spine

questions.solution:
This patient’s young age and progressive back pain, along with a family history of an inflammatory condition of the spine, and the presence of sacroiliitis and enthesitis indicates ankylosing spondylitis. This diagnosis is further supported by the presence of an elevated ESR and a positive HLA-B27. Spinal stiffness and reduced range of motion of the spine would also be expected.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, resulting in erosion of bone and destruction of articular tissue. This ultimately leads to fibrosis and calcification, causing fusion of the involved vertebrae and loss of range of motion. The disease is more common in males, and age of onset is usually < 40 years. Important risk factors include having a first-degree relative with the disease and HLA-B27 positivity.

Patients typically present with back pain of insidious onset that is worse at night or with inactivity, and improves with exercise. On physical examination, tenderness in the sacroiliac joints indicates sacroiliitis. Diminished range of motion of the spine is often present as the disease progresses, and can be evaluated using the Schober test as shown below. Arthritis of peripheral joints can also be seen in about half of patients, as well as enthesitis, tendonitis, and dactylitis. Extra-articular manifestations can include pulmonary fibrosis, inflammatory bowel disease, uveitis, and aortitis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Spinal stiffness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperlordosis of the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: Hyperlordosis, or an excessive inward curve of the lumbar spine above the buttocks, is more commonly associated with conditions like obesity, inactivity, and spondylolisthesis. This finding is not typically seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, where stiffness and reduced mobility are more characteristic.  
❌ Increased range of motion of the spine:
Incorrect: This finding is more consistent with hypermobility syndromes (e.g. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). Ankylosing spondylitis typically leads to decreased spinal mobility due to inflammation with subsequent spinal fusion.  
❌ Hyperflexion of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: Hyperflexion of the cervical spine is experienced by patients with whiplash injuries when there is hyperextension followed by hyperflexion of the cervical spine leading to pain. It is not a characteristic feature of ankylosing spondylitis, where limited cervical mobility is more commonly seen.  
❌ Increased lateral curvature and rotation of the spine:
Incorrect: Increased lateral curvature (scoliosis) and rotation are more indicative of structural spinal deformities, like idiopathic scoliosis or neuromuscular conditions. They are not typical of ankylosing spondylitis, which is characterized by low back pain and stiffness with a reduced range of motion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for follow-up after being treated for low back pain that improves with exercise and worsens with rest. He was prescribed medical treatment for this condition 6 weeks ago, and he has been taking the medications as prescribed but continues to have pain and stiffness. On physical examination, there is decreased lumbar flexion and pain in the sacroiliac joints with direct palpation. Laboratory findings include elevated C-reactive protein and ESR levels, and a negative HLA-B27. Radiographs of the sacroiliac joints show evidence of bilateral sacroiliitis. The patient is started on etanercept therapy. Which of the following would be an indication for initiating a TNF inhibitor in this patient?

choices.text: Inadequate response to daily maximal doses of two different NSAIDs
Inadequate response to as-needed doses of naproxen

questions.solution:
This patient’s history, examination, and imaging findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. This patient has been prescribed the biologic DMARD etanercept. Indications for the use of biologic DMARDs in AS include inadequate response to daily maximal doses of two different NSAIDs and contraindications to NSAID use.

The primary objectives in managing ankylosing spondylitis are relieving symptoms and maintaining mobility and functioning. Non-pharmacologic management, such as physical therapy, exercise, and smoking cessation should be recommended to all patients with ankylosing spondylitis.

Most symptomatic patients with AS should be started on NSAID therapy (e.g., naproxen) initially. These medications are often effective for relieving the pain and stiffness associated with ankylosing spondylitis. NSAIDs should be started at full antiinflammatory doses given on a regular continuing basis for at least two to four weeks before switching to a second NSAID if response is inadequate. If the response is adequate, then patients can be switched to as-needed dosing.

Patients who have an inadequate response to NSAIDs require more intensive therapy with a biologic DMARD like a TNF inhibitor. These medications reduce chronic inflammation by suppressing the immune system; however, patients are at risk of developing infections. Appropriate screenings (e.g. tuberculosis) and vaccinations are necessary before initiating biologic DMARDs. Unlike in rheumatoid arthritis, there is no indication of using the TNF inhibitors in combination with conventional synthetic DMARDS or steroids.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inadequate response to daily maximal doses of two different NSAIDs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inadequate response to as-needed doses of naproxen:
Incorrect: Initial therapy of AS should be regularly scheduled inflammatory doses of NSAIDs given for two to four weeks. If an adequate response is achieved, then as-needed doses may be used. As-needed-dosing should not be used initially to determine response to NSAIDs in AS.  
❌ Combination use with methotrexate:
Incorrect: Any TNF inhibitor can be used alone for treatment of AS that is unresponsive to NSAID therapy. Unlike in rheumatoid arthritis, combination therapy with a conventional DMARD like methotrexate is not recommended.  
❌ Combination use with sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Any TNF inhibitor can be used alone for treatment of AS that is unresponsive to NSAID therapy. Unlike in rheumatoid arthritis, combination therapy with a conventional DMARD like sulfasalazine is not recommended.  
❌ Inadequate response to moderate-dose prednisone:
Incorrect: Systemic glucocorticoids are ineffective for AS in low to moderate doses, and they are not indicated in AS. Initial therapy should be started with NSAIDs prescribed at regularly scheduled inflammatory doses for two to four weeks. Biologic DMARDs should be used in patients with inadequate response or contraindications to NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of a new facial rash. The rash worsens with sun exposure. The patient has also experienced painful oral ulcers, joint pain, and hair loss. She has no significant past medical history. Her mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Physical examination reveals a bright red butterfly-like rash on the cheeks and nose, sparing the nasolabial folds. ANA titer is 1:320. She was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and started on oral prednisone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which glucocorticoids exert their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effect?

choices.text: Decreased expression of nuclear factor-kappa beta (NF-κB)

questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to manage systemic lupus erythematosus. Glucocorticoids are a class of medication often used due to their immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory properties.    

Glucocorticoids bind to cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptors. The glucocorticoid-receptor complexes then translocate to the nucleus, where they bind to glucocorticoid response elements (GREs) on chromatin and regulate gene expression.    

Most notably, glucocorticoids inhibit the production of NF-κB, a transcription factor that assists in synthesizing pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-2, TNF-α). Moreover, glucocorticoids suppress B- and T-cell function and induce T-cell apoptosis.     

Moreover, glucocorticoids increase insulin resistance and are diabetogenic. Patients can develop hyperglycemia since insulin is no longer as effective at causing cells to take up glucose. This medication class also triggers gluconeogenesis via lipolysis to release free fatty acids and muscle proteolysis to release free amino acids, which are then used to synthesize glucose molecules. Overall, glucocorticoids have a catabolic effect on the body.  



Option Analysis

❌ Increased T-lymphocyte production:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids induce apoptosis of lymphocytes, eosinophils, and monocytes.
❌ Decreased expression of IL-10:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids increase the expression of IL-10, which promotes the expression of anti-inflammatory genes.
✅ Decreased expression of nuclear factor-kappa beta (NF-κB):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased expression of phospholipase A2:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids decrease the expression of prostaglandins and leukotrienes via the inhibition of phospholipase A2.
❌ Increased activation of activating protein-1 (AP-1):
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids suppress the production of AP-1, a transcription factor that promotes the expression of pro-inflammatory genes.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with three months of fatigue and severe wrist and hand pain that started two months ago but has worsened in the past few days. She has also been experiencing hair loss and ulcers in her mouth. The patient has no known past medical history. Temperature is 37.4 ºC (99.3 ºF), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 146/91 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there are several areas of alopecia and multiple aphthous ulcers in the mouth. The lungs are clear to auscultation, cardiac exam is within normal limits. Multiple proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation with evidence of effusions. Serum white blood cell count is 1,800/mm<sup>3</sup> and platelet count is 96,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Which of the following clinical or diagnostic findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Arthrocentesis showing > 100,000 white blood cells/mm3 in the synovial fluid

questions.solution:
This 33-year-old woman presents with arthritis of the small joints of both hands that have been present for more than three months, along with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias. Together, these findings suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and the classic butterfly or malar rash would most likely be seen on a physical exam.

For patients presenting with subacute or chronic joint pain (≥ 6 weeks) involving multiple joints, a combination of history, physical exam, imaging findings of involved joints, and diagnostic blood work can help determine the diagnosis. In patients with active synovitis (tender, warm, swollen, erythematous joints) and elevated inflammatory markers ESR and CRP, inflammatory arthritis should be suspected. Initial blood work can include ESR, CRP, ANA (SLE and other autoimmune conditions), and rheumatoid factor (RF). Based on these results, further blood work may be needed to narrow down the diagnosis and can include anti-CCP antibody (RA), HLA B27 (ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis), anti-ds DNA and anti-smith antibodies (SLE), anti-Scl 70 (scleroderma), and anti-SSA and anti-SSB (Sjögren syndrome). The specific diagnosis will be made based on a combination of clinical findings, laboratory results, and imaging findings.

SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems in addition to the joints of the musculoskeletal system, and patients can present with a myriad of signs and symptoms reflecting the particular organs involved. Patients with inflammatory arthritis tend to have migratory symmetric polyarthritis. Most patients have skin and mucous membrane involvement at some point in their diseases. The most common skin manifestation is the classic “butterfly” rash after sun exposure, which appears as a malar rash over the cheeks and nose, but sparing the nasolabial folds.  

Option Analysis

✅ Malar rash:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Low back pain and stiffness:
Incorrect: Low back pain is associated with spondyloarthritis (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis), which typically presents as chronic low back pain and stiffness in young men with a family history of chronic back pain. This patient who presents with arthritis in multiple small joints of the hands associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Pencil-in-cup deformity on hand radiographs:
Incorrect: This deformity refers to the appearance of severe, erosive joint destruction in the DIP joints. It is a finding that can be seen in psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is typically associated with asymmetric oligoarthritis, nail deformities, dactylitis, and skin psoriasis. This patient presenting with small joint arthritis associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Arthrocentesis showing > 100,000 white blood cells/mm3 in the synovial fluid:
Incorrect: This degree of elevation of the white blood cell count in the synovial fluid is consistent with septic arthritis which typically presents as one warm, swollen, and exquisitely tender joint. This patient who presents with small joint polyarthritis associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Positive anti-SSA autoantibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies are found in Sjögren syndrome. Patients with Sjogrens may have arthritis and leukopenia; however, they also typically have sicca symptoms (dry eyes, dry mouth).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of 6 months of morning stiffness, pain, and swelling in the knees and right ankle. Additionally, the child has experienced low back pain and stiffness that is worse in the morning and improves with exercise, and discomfort in the left heel. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling, tenderness, and limited range of motion in the knees bilaterally and the right ankle. There is tenderness at the insertion sites of the left Achilles and patellar tendons bilaterally. There is limited anterior flexion at the lower spine and pain with palpation at the bilateral sacroiliac joints. Laboratory results from the original clinic visit are reviewed. Which of the following findings would be specific for the likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s age, symptoms, and examination findings (e.g., asymmetric oligoarthritis, lumbar and sacroiliac involvement, enthesitis) are consistent with enthesitis-related juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). This subtype of JIA is associated with a positive HLA-B27.

JIA is a group of autoimmune diseases that cause chronic joint inflammation in children and are characterized by swelling, pain, and stiffness in the joints. This can lead to decreased mobility and potential long-term damage if not effectively managed. There are several subtypes of JIA based on the number of joints affected, the presence of certain associated findings like rash or enthesitis, and the results of specific laboratory tests. The subtypes include systemic, polyarticular, oligoarticular, psoriatic, and enthesitis-related JIA.

While no single test can definitively diagnose JIA, a combination of clinical findings and laboratory results can help to identify the specific subtype of JIA and guide treatment decisions. Laboratory tests may include complete blood count to evaluate for anemia, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP) to assess for inflammation, rheumatoid factor (RF), and antinuclear antibody (ANA) tests to detect autoantibodies. Imaging studies may be used to assess for joint damage and inflammation. Typical laboratory abnormalities vary by JIA subtype but may include elevated ESR and CRP in most types. Positive ANA is seen in some cases of oligoarticular or polyarticular JIA, and negative RF is seen in most types (except in some cases of polyarticular JIA, usually in children 10 years of age or older). Additionally, HLA-B27 may be positive in cases of enthesitis-related JIA.       

Option Analysis

✅ Positive HLA-B27:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate:
Incorrect: Elevated inflammatory markers are nonspecific and can be seen with multiple subtypes of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), including polyarticular and enthesitis-related JIA. 
❌ Elevated C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: Elevated inflammatory markers are nonspecific and can be seen with multiple subtypes of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), including polyarticular and enthesitis-related JIA. 
❌ Positive antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and exam are consistent with enthesitis-related JIA, which is typically associated with a negative ANA. 
❌ Positive rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and exam are consistent with enthesitis-related JIA, which is typically associated with a negative rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician for evaluation of intermittent low-grade fevers for one month. She reports significant fatigue and malaise along with headaches, arthralgia, myalgias, and loss of appetite. She has a history of ADHD well-controlled with lisdexamfetamine. Immunizations are up to date. She is at the 80<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and 48<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100%. On physical examination, there is thinning of the hair at the frontotemporal area. There is an erythematous rash over the nasal bridge that extends to her cheeks but spares the nasolabial folds. Mucus membranes are moist and oral ulcers are visualized. There is no murmur. Lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no increased work of breathing. Which of the following tests would confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent low-grade fevers, malaise, and arthralgias/myalgias. And findings of hair thinning, oral ulcers, and malar rash. The most likely diagnosis is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Positive anti-dsDNA antibodies would confirm the diagnosis.

In children with fever once infection has been ruled out then malignancy should be considered. After malignancy has been ruled out, then inflammatory disorders should be considered. Kawasaki disease and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA) are clinical diagnoses. Patients with Kawasaki disease must have ≥ 5 days of fever and meet 4 out of 5 specific criteria. Atypical Kawasaki disease allows for laboratory and echocardiogram findings to aid in diagnosis. Diagnosis of sJIA is made when a patient has fever for ≥ 2 weeks and arthritis for ≥ 6 weeks and other causes have been ruled out. Diagnosis of SLE is made based on history and physical examination findings and positive ANA, anti-ds DNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies.

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy can diagnose inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) which may in some cases cause fever, however, this patient has no abdominal symptoms. The presence of alopecia, malar rash, and oral ulcers makes systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) more likely.
❌ Magnetic resonance imagine (MRI):
Incorrect: MRI is not typically indicated as part of the evaluation of suspected systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Evaluation should start with autoantibody testing including anti double stranded DNA antibodies.
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: In the setting of fever, a bone marrow biopsy is performed when there is concern for leukemia or later in the work-up for a fever of unknown origin (FUO). This patient's signs symptoms and findings are more consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and serologic antibody testing should be performed.
❌ Rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor is not specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In patients with suspected SLE testing should begin with antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-double-stranded DNA, and anti-Smith antibody testing.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 4-week history of intermittent fevers and a 3-week history of joint pain affecting both knees. The fevers come and go daily and when they are present, they are associated with an evanescent, macular, salmon-colored rash. The parents report that the child has been unwell with fatigue and reduced appetite over the past 4 weeks. They live near a wooded area and mention that the child had a tick bite several months ago. The child has had multiple visits to urgent care. He was prescribed a course of amoxicillin and laboratory studies were sent, which can be seen below. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, no rashes are currently present. Both knees are swollen, tender, and painful with passive and active range of motion. Generalized lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory study     Result   
 White blood cells (WBC)     22,000/m3    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     88 mm/hr    
 Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)     Negative    
 Rheumatoid factor     Negative    
 Ferritin     >1200 ng/mL    
 Lyme ELISA     Equivocal    
 Lyme IgM Western blot     24 kDa band present    
 Lyme IgG Western blot     18 and 21 kDa bands present
questions.solution:
The patient’s systemic symptoms of fever associated with a salmon-colored rash and arthritis are consistent with systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). He should be referred to rheumatology for immunosuppressive therapy, such as a monoclonal antibody.

Systemic JIA is a subtype of JIA, distinguished by repeated, spiking fevers accompanied by a characteristic salmon-colored rash. Other systemic manifestations include lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis. Laboratory abnormalities are common, including elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR, CRP, ferritin), anemia, and leukocytosis. 

The condition is often misdiagnosed initially, which often leads to a delay in appropriate treatment. Once the diagnosis is made, management focuses on reducing inflammation and depends on the severity of the disease. Mild disease can be treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and glucocorticoids. Moderate-to-severe disease often requires biologic agents, such as IL-1 or IL-6 inhibitors.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rheumatology referral for immunosuppressive therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Course of doxycycline:
Incorrect: This patient’s Western blot does not meet the criteria to be considered a positive result for Lyme disease (positive test requires 2 IgM bands or 5 IgG bands). This suggests that antibiotics would not address the underlying cause of symptoms. 
❌ Serology for Epstein-Barr virus:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis can cause fatigue, fever, and lymphadenopathy, but it would not cause the arthritis/ synovitis seen in this patient. A salmon-colored rash can occur after the administration of amoxicillin in patients with EBV and mononucleosis. However, this patient’s rash occurred before taking amoxicillin and is only present during fever spikes. 
❌ Acetaminophen and observation:
Incorrect: While acetaminophen can be used for general pain and fever management, it does not address the underlying inflammatory process. This patient has signs and symptoms concerning systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 
❌ Strict bed rest:
Incorrect: This recommendation is inappropriate because it does not address the underlying inflammatory process and could potentially worsen outcomes by promoting joint stiffness and muscle atrophy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with her parents who are concerned that she has been experiencing pain in the left knee and right ankle for the past two months. They note that she appears to have difficulty walking after waking up in the morning. The parents have also noticed a rash on her scalp. She has no significant past medical history, and her vaccinations are up-to-date. On physical examination, there is a well-demarcated, erythematous rash covered with silver scales on her scalp and behind both ears. There is swelling, warmth, and pain with range of motion in the left knee and right ankle and swelling and tenderness to palpation over the insertion site of the right Achilles tendon. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with this patient’s likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents with signs and symptoms (e.g., a rash with silvery scale, arthritis, enthesitis) consistent with psoriatic juvenile idiopathic psoriasis (JIA). Nail findings, such as nail pitting and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the bed) are seen in more than half of cases.

JIA has multiple subtypes with variable clinical features. Psoriatic JIA is characterized by the presence of arthritis (e.g., joint pain, morning stiffness, reduced range of motion) along with skin features of psoriasis (erythematous plaques with a silvery scale). Frank skin psoriasis may not always be present in children, but they may have other distinctive signs of psoriatic JIA such as nail pitting, dactylitis, and/or enthesitis.

Other subtypes of JIA present other distinctive features and findings. Patients with systemic JIA typically present with fever, which is associated with an evanescent, migratory, salmon-pink-colored rash that disappears with the resolution of the fever. There are often other systemic features, such as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis. Patients with oligoarticular JIA present with joint pain and swelling affecting < 5 joints. They may have evidence of joint disuse such as muscle atrophy and contractures. Leg length discrepancies may also be seen. It is typically seen in children around 2–3 years of age. Patients with polyarticular JIA have similar signs and symptoms involving ≥ 5 joints. Patients with enthesitis-related JIA are often older and present with sacroiliitis and anterior uveitis.       

Option Analysis

✅ Nail pitting:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ High fever:
Incorrect: A high fever, often accompanied by a migratory salmon-pink rash, is indicative of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). The rash described for this patient is more consistent with that seen in psoriatic JIA. 
❌ Muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Muscle atrophy can occur with chronic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), most often with subtypes that present in young children (e.g., oligoarticular JIA), and lead to disuse of the affected limb. This patient’s rash and other findings are more consistent with psoriatic JIA. 
❌ Eye redness associated with pain:
Incorrect: Chronic uveitis can occur with psoriatic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. However, it is typically painless. 
❌ Lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Lymphadenopathy is common with systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). The rash and symptoms described in this patient’s vignette are more consistent with psoriatic JIA which is not associated with lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with left shoulder pain. The pain started insidiously two weeks ago and tends to be worse at night. She has also experienced decreased range of motion in the left shoulder. The patient did not sustain any recent injuries. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient demonstrates limited active and passive range of motion, with associated pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with insidious subacute left shoulder pain with global stiffness, as well as limited active and passive range of motion. The shoulder radiograph is unremarkable. Together, these findings suggest adhesive capsulitis (also termed frozen shoulder syndrome).

Adhesive capsulitis is a poorly understood condition that results in global stiffness and pain of the glenohumeral joint. Current research postulates the condition results from spontaneous inflammation of the joint capsule, followed by the development of adhesions and fibrosis of the synovial lining. Clinically, patients present with subacute symptoms including deep, nagging shoulder pain and associated limitations in passive and active range of motion (particularly external rotation and abduction). The condition is often idiopathic but has been associated with a history of shoulder injury, diabetes, dyslipidemia, Parkinson disease, immobilization, and antiretroviral therapy.

The disease progresses through three distinct phases. First, patients experience an acute phase characterized by severe disabling shoulder pain that worsens at night, with some associated stiffness. This phase lasts 2-9 months. Next, an intermediate phase occurs wherein pain decreases but stiffness and severe loss of shoulder motion ensues. This phase lasts 4-12 months. Finally, a recovery phase occurs, wherein patients regain shoulder mobility.

Diagnosis of adhesive capsulitis is primarily clinical, as imaging findings are generally noncontributory, and radiographs are often normal. Since most cases are self-limited, management is conservative and involves a combination of rest, analgesia, and physical therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: Glenohumeral osteoarthritis more commonly occurs in older adults with a prior history of shoulder surgery or trauma. In addition, this condition presents chronically, developing over the course of months to years. Radiographic findings of glenohumeral osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and can present similarly to adhesive capsulitis. However, patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common form of shoulder dislocation. Patients with anterior shoulder dislocation will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Humeral head fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a fracture pattern on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to progressive pain, redness, and swelling of the left foot for the past week, and 2 days of fevers and chills. Four weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with a diabetic foot ulcer on the plantar surface at the base of the first left toe. Past medical history is significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.9°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 93/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals an erythematous, swollen left foot with an open 2 ½ cm ulcer on the plantar surface at the base of the left toe. The foot is warm to the touch, and there is tenderness to palpation at the site of the ulcer and purulent discharge is present. Bone is felt when probing the ulcer with a sterile surgical probe. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a white blood cell (WBC) count of 18,000/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) of 120 mg/L, and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 350 U/L. Intravenous fluids are initiated and blood and wound cultures are sent. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the foot and intravenous clindamycin

questions.solution:
This patient with DM and a diabetic foot ulcer presents with progressive pain, redness, and swelling at the site of a prior ulcer. On a physical exam he has a positive probe-to-bone test, and signs of systemic infection and sepsis. The most likely diagnosis is acute osteomyelitis from a diabetic foot ulcer. Management should include hemodynamic stabilization and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics that cover streptococci, MRSA, aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes. An appropriate regimen would be vancomycin, metronidazole, and cefepime.

The initial step in the acute management of an unstable patient with acute osteomyelitis is stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation; obtaining IV access; and initiating IV fluids. Once blood and wound cultures are obtained, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started. The empiric antibiotic regimen for osteomyelitis from diabetic foot ulcers should be based on the severity of the infection and the likelihood of resistant organisms. For patients with systemic toxicity or limb-threatening infections, antibiotics should cover streptococci, MRSA, aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes. Diagnostic imaging, typically with X-ray and MRI, should be performed after empiric antibiotics are started. Surgery should be consulted for possible debridement. A prolonged course of targeted antibiotics should be guided by culture and sensitivity results.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous vancomycin, metronidazole, and cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis due to acute osteomyelitis from a diabetic foot ulcer. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and inpatient care are necessary due to the severity of the condition.  
❌ Immediate surgical debridement:
Incorrect: While surgical debridement may be required in the management of osteomyelitis in patients with diabetic foot ulcers, it is not the immediate priority in this case. The patient should first be stabilized and treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.  
❌ Bone biopsy and intravenous ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis due to acute osteomyelitis. A bone biopsy is used to definitively diagnose osteomyelitis, but this patient with hemodynamic instability and sepsis should first be started on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Ceftriaxone alone is not broad enough coverage for this patient.  
❌ MRI of the foot and intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: While MRI can provide detailed information regarding the extent of osteomyelitis, it should not delay the initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, empiric clindamycin alone is not sufficient.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and peripheral vascular disease presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of persistent lower back pain. The pain is described as constant, worse at night, and it does not improve with over-the-counter analgesics. Six weeks ago, the patient underwent a lumbar epidural corticosteroid injection for treatment of left lower extremity radicular pain. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 146/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. There is spinal tenderness to palpation, erythema, and swelling at L3 and L4. The pain worsens with hyperextension or flexion of the spine. There are no neurological deficits. Laboratory results are shown below. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test results and blood and urine cultures are pending. A spinal X-ray shows degenerative changes but no acute pathology. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin      14 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     13,100/mm3    
 Platelet count      450,000/mm3    
 Creatinine      0.9 mg/dL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)      77 mm/hr    
 C-reactive protein     15 mg/L

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the lumbar spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine
18F–fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) and computed tomography
Lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint X-rays

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent lower back pain, fever, spinal tenderness erythema, swelling, elevated leukocyte count, markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and C-reactive protein (CRP) following a lumbar epidural corticosteroid injection. This clinical picture is concerning for a spinal infection such as osteomyelitis, and a lumbar spine MRI with and without contrast should be ordered for diagnosis after spinal X-ray and blood cultures are obtained. CT is a reasonable alternative diagnostic study that can be ordered if MRI is not available or contraindicated.        

When patients present with back pain, the history and physical exam and the presence or absence of alarm features can help determine whether further diagnostic workup with imaging is necessary. In patients who present with saddle anesthesia or loss of sensation around the buttocks, perineum, and inner thighs and absent or decreased anal sphincter tone, cauda equina syndrome should be suspected, and a spinal X-ray and MRI should be ordered. Patients with fever and risk factors for infectious causes of back pain should also have spinal X-ray and MRI. If patients have a history of cancer, unexplained weight loss, or night sweats, malignancy should be suspected. Imaging should be performed, which might show a vertebral tumor or metastatic lesions; then, biopsy should be obtained. Patients with spinal stenosis are typically elderly with back pain that is relieved by bending forward. Spinal X-ray or MRI will typically show signs of spinal stenosis. In patients with severe back pain and a history of osteoporosis or trauma, spinal fracture should be suspected; and X-ray, spine CT, and MRI should be ordered. Patients with signs of radiculopathy who have not responded to conservative management should have MRI imaging for suspected disc herniation. In patients with pain with movement and an inciting incident like lifting heavy objects, lumbar strain/sprain should be suspected; if no red flag findings are present, then imaging is not necessary.   

Option Analysis

❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: CT of the lumbar spine would be appropriate if the patient were unable to undergo MRI (e.g. due to hardware implantation). However, MRI allows for better visualization of the soft tissue structures of the lumbar spine and is, therefore, the preferred imaging modality when osteomyelitis is suspected. 
✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 18F–fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) and computed tomography:
Incorrect: 18F–FDG-PET/CT is a highly sensitive means of detecting vertebral osteomyelitis and can be considered in the diagnostic workup of complex spinal pathology when other studies are negative and suspicion for infection or malignancy remains high. The current gold standard in imaging of suspected vertebral osteomyelitis is MRI for its specificity and anatomic detail.  
❌ Lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint X-rays :
Incorrect: The patient's older age at presentation and history of recent spinal procedure that would predispose him to infection are more consistent with a spinal infection rather than ankylosing spondylitis, which typically presents in young males with inflammatory back pain and can be seen on imaging of the sacroiliac joints and spine. 
❌ Bone biopsy:
Incorrect: While a bone biopsy can confirm osteomyelitis and identify the causative organism, it is invasive and typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis remains unclear after imaging, or when there is inadequate response to empirical treatment with antibiotics. MRI should precede a biopsy in the diagnostic process for suspected spinal infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for three weeks of severe lower back pain that is worse with movement, chills, and intermittent fevers. She has a history of injection drug use. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), heart rate is 112/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lumbar spine at L3 and a 4/6 holosystolic murmur is best heard at the left sternal border. Neurological examination is within normal limits. Laboratory findings are significant for a white blood cell (WBC) count of 15,500/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) of 130 mg/L, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 120 mm/h. Spine x-rays show L3 vertebral body destruction and collapse of the intervertebral disc space. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of acute lower back pain and tenderness, fevers and chills, history of intravenous drug use, and x-ray findings suggests acute vertebral osteomyelitis. The presence of a 4/6 holosystolic murmur raises concern for infective endocarditis with bacteremia and hematogenous spread to the vertebral column. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients who use IV drugs, and it is known for its aggressive nature and propensity to affect bones and heart valves.

Patients with acute osteomyelitis typically exhibit localized pain at the infection site, often accompanied by tenderness, swelling, and warmth. Systemic symptoms such as fevers and chills frequently occur. In chronic osteomyelitis, symptoms can be more subtle and insidious, such as a continuous dull ache or localized discomfort at the site of infection. Intravenous drug use is a risk factor for vertebral osteomyelitis. Patients can present with severe back pain, fever, chills, weight loss, and neurological signs and symptoms such as incontinence or focal neurologic deficits.  

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Coxiella burnetii:
Incorrect: Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, can lead to endocarditis, primarily in patients with chronic disease or certain occupational exposures like livestock handling. However, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Streptococcus mutans:
Incorrect: While Streptococcus mutans is associated with endocarditis, it is not a common cause of osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Candida albicans can cause chronic osteomyelitis, primarily in immunocompromised patients or in patients with prolonged central venous access. This patient's lack of evident immunosuppression and acute presentation make Candida a less likely pathogen. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Mycobacterium tuberculosis can cause spinal tuberculosis (Pott’s disease), but it typically presents with a more chronic course. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of osteomyelitis associated with endocarditis. US guided biopsy should be performed and cultures should test for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to rule it out.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of progressive pain in his left leg above the knee. He has not had recent trauma but reports intermittent fevers and chills over the past week. Past medical history is significant for sickle cell disease. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate is 102/min, blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The distal left femur is tender to palpation with swelling and erythema. There is no overlying skin wound, and range of motion in the knee is preserved. Results of the laboratory evaluation are shown below. X-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Test
Result
White Blood Cell Count  
16,500/µL  
Hemoglobin
8.6 g/dL  
Hematocrit
26.1%  
Platelet Count  
340,000 /µL  
Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.1 mEq/L  
Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL  
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)  
70 mm/hr  
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)  
55 mg/L

choices.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the extremity

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of sickle cell disease presents with signs suggestive of acute osteomyelitis including progressive leg pain, fever, localized tenderness, swelling and erythema, and evidence of inflammation in bloodwork. The initial x-rays are normal, but this is commonly seen in early osteomyelitis. The clinical suspicion of osteomyelitis remains high, and MRI of the extremity should be performed next.

MRI is sensitive and specific for the detection of early osteomyelitis. It can identify findings like bone marrow edema, periosteal reaction, and subcutaneous edema before bony changes are evident on x-rays. It should be performed in patients with suspected acute osteomyelitis and negative x-ray findings or findings on x-ray that are suspicious of osteomyelitis.

Bone scintigraphy, or bone scan, is highly sensitive for osteomyelitis but lacks specificity; it can detect increased bone activity and is useful when MRI is contraindicated, such as in the presence of metal implants, but it cannot differentiate osteomyelitis from other inflammatory bone conditions.

CT scan provides excellent bone detail and is useful for diagnosing chronic osteomyelitis. It can visualize dead bone fragments and surrounding sclerosis and thickening, but it is less sensitive than MRI in the early stages of the disease.

A bone biopsy can be used as the gold standard of diagnosis and to identify the causative organism to tailor antibiotic treatment.
 
MRI shows abnormal heterogeneous marrow signal intensity of the distal tibial metaphysis & diaphysis (black solid arrows) with overlying periosteal & soft tissue edema (white solid arrow). StatDX  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pain management and IV hydration:
Incorrect: Acute vaso-occlusive pain episodes in the long bones secondary to sickle cell disease may be difficult to differentiate from osteomyelitis. Pain management and IV hydration is the mainstay of treatment for acute vaso-occlusive pain episodes. However, in this patient, there is high suspicion of osteomyelitis, and he should have an MRI.  
❌ CT of the extremity:
Incorrect: CT may be used to help diagnose osteomyelitis when MRI is contraindicated. However, in acute osteomyelitis, MRI is preferred. For diagnosing chronic osteomyelitis, CT is generally preferred.  
❌ Bone scintigraphy (bone scan)  :
Incorrect: Bone scan can be performed in the workup of acute osteomyelitis when MRI is contraindicated, such as if metal implants are present. However, it lacks specificity and cannot distinguish between osteomyelitis and other conditions like fractures or tumors. MRI is preferred in most cases in early osteomyelitis for its sensitivity and specificity.  
❌ CT-guided bone biopsy:
Incorrect: Although bone biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis and is used to identify the causative organism and tailor antibiotic treatment in the management of acute osteomyelitis, identifying the most likely diagnosis and extent of disease with MRI is the best next step in the management of this patient.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-week history of progressive painless swelling of his lower jaw. This past week, he started having drainage from the overlying skin which prompted him to get evaluated. He had extensive dental work 10 weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes metformin and insulin. He has no known drug allergies. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a swollen indurated area of the mandible at the angle of the lower jaw on the left with yellow granules in the discharge from two distinct sinus tracts open to the skin. Laboratory tests show a white blood cell count of 17,500/µL and C-reactive protein of 45 mg/L. Radiographs of the jaw show left jaw bone destruction with periosteal reaction. Gram stain of the fluid shows filaments as seen below with culture pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Taken from the Public Health Image Library (PHIL)

choices.text: Intravenous penicillin G and surgical debridement
Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up in 1 week
Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam with surgical debridement
Oral ciprofloxacin and clindamycin with outpatient follow-up in 1 week

questions.solution:
This patient with poorly controlled DM and recent dental work presents with progressive painless swelling and induration of the mandible. X-rays show bone destruction with periosteal reaction suggestive of osteomyelitis of the jaw. The presence of draining sinus tracts with yellow “sulfur granules” and gram-positive filamentous bacteria on gram stains suggests Actinomyces infection. This patient should be treated with intravenous (IV) penicillin G and surgical debridement of the affected area. Beta-lactam antibiotics are particularly effective against Actinomyces, and surgical intervention is necessary to remove necrotic tissue.

Patients suspected of having osteomyelitis should have blood cultures and wound cultures (if possible) taken, followed by empiric intravenous antibiotics. Definitive diagnosis is made with a bone biopsy. The choice of empiric therapy is guided by determining the likely organisms based on patient history, risk factors, and local resistance patterns. Once culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotics should be tailored to the identified pathogen. In cases of chronic osteomyelitis, or when the infection is complicated by the presence of necrotic bone, soft tissue abscess, or sinus tracts, surgical debridement is typically necessary in addition to a long course of antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous penicillin G and surgical debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up in 1 week:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis of the jaw caused by Actinomyces. Although amoxicillin-clavulanate can cover Actinomyces, a single beta-lactam agent like penicillin G usually provides sufficient coverage and intravenous therapy with surgical debridement will be necessary in this patient due to the extent of the infection with sinus tract formation.  
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam with surgical debridement:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis caused by Actinomycosis species, which is highly susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin G. Broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage is not indicated for this infection.  
❌ Oral ciprofloxacin and clindamycin with outpatient follow-up in 1 week:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis of the jaw caused by Actinomyces, which is highly susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics. Clindamycin can be prescribed for patients with a penicillin allergy, but this patient has no known drug allergies. Additionally, surgical debridement will be necessary in this patient given that he has multiple draining sinus tracts.  
❌ Intravenous fluconazole and surgical debridement:
Incorrect: This patient has osteomyelitis caused by Actinomyces. Although Actinomyces has a filamentous appearance similar to fungi, it is a bacterium. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication and not indicated for bacterial infections like actinomycosis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of left shoulder pain. The patient developed pain over the past two days and does not recall any preceding injury or trauma. He has pain with movement of the shoulder and when he is not moving it. The patient has also been experiencing chills and generalized fatigue over the same time period. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gout, and Crohn disease. Medications include amlodipine, simvastatin, allopurinol, and infliximab. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg. The patient appears fatigued. Physical examination demonstrates swelling, significant tenderness to palpation, and warmth over the left shoulder. The patient has significant pain and limited range of motion with both passive and active range of motion at the left shoulder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Referral to the emergency department for arthrocentesis
Discharge home with ibuprofen and reassess in two days

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of atraumatic shoulder pain. He has constitutional symptoms as well as physical examination findings of swelling, tenderness, warmth, and significantly limited active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder that is concerning for septic arthritis. In addition, this patient's history of immunosuppression places him at risk for this condition. Therefore, the next best step in management is referral to the emergency department for further workup via blood work and arthrocentesis given the time-sensitive and life/limb threatening nature of this condition.   

Shoulder pain is a common symptom with many underlying causes, including conditions affecting the joint, capsule, tendons, or bursa. When performing a history and physical examination for a patient with shoulder pain, the first step is to identify if the patient’s shoulder pain is due to trauma or infection.    

When a clear history of trauma is present, patients should be further assessed regarding chronicity, mechanism, and limitations in movement or functional status. Physical examination should focus on assessment of deformity, skin changes, and neurovascular status. In addition, certain physical examination maneuvers may assist in the diagnosis (e.g. O’brien test for labral pathology).    

When infection is suspected, patients should be assessed for systemic symptoms, like fever; chills; myalgias; and localized tenderness, swelling, and warmth. Additional clues may include a history of immunosuppression. If there are signs of infection, patients should undergo further evaluation for septic arthritis or osteomyelitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Referral to the emergency department for arthrocentesis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ X-ray of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: This patient presents with atraumatic shoulder pain, constitutional symptoms, and a physical examination concerning for potential septic arthritis. Referral to the emergency department is the most appropriate next step in management.  
❌ Discharge home with ibuprofen and reassess in two days:
Incorrect: This patient presents with atraumatic shoulder pain, constitutional symptoms, and a physical examination concerning for potential septic arthritis. Despite the patient's history of gout, he should be referred to the emergency department for arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis.  
❌ Uric acid level :
Incorrect: This patient presents with atraumatic shoulder pain, constitutional symptoms, and a physical examination concerning for potential septic arthritis. Despite the patient's history of gout, he should be referred to the emergency department for further evaluation with arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. Uric acid levels can be unreliable during gout flares.  
❌ Outpatient shoulder magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: A shoulder MRI may reveal changes such as effusion or inflammatory changes within the joint space in patients with septic arthritis; however, additional diagnostic steps should be pursued prior to imaging, including blood work and synovial fluid analysis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of three weeks of worsening right foot pain. He has had a chronic, non-healing ulcer over his heel for four months, but it did not initially cause him pain due to having decreased sensation from diabetic neuropathy. Three weeks ago, he noticed redness and swelling around the area and pain deep within the foot. His past medical history includes poorly controlled insulin-dependent type II diabetes and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg.  On examination, there is a stage 3 ulcer over the plantar surface of the right foot at the heel with surrounding erythema, warmth, and edema that extends to the ankle. In addition to laboratory studies, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the foot
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the foot
Combined positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient likely has osteomyelitis of the foot, as evidenced by a grade 3 ulcer surrounded by erythema, warmth, and edema in the setting of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus. Initial diagnostic testing for osteomyelitis typically includes obtaining both a plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging of the foot when available, along with blood cultures, complete blood count, and inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Bone biopsy can provide a definitive diagnosis when needed. 

Fractures, joint dislocations, arthritis, and other causes of bony pain like calcaneal spur) can typically be diagnosed via X-ray imaging. Neuropathic pain caused by diabetic neuropathy can be diagnosed clinically. Patients with tarsal tunnel syndrome or neuropathy without a clear cause may benefit from evaluation via electromyography (EMG) and nerve-conduction study. Ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging are helpful when a mass is suspected (e.g., morton neuroma). Most dermatologic causes of foot pain can be diagnosed clinically, but laboratory and imaging studies may be needed in patients with deep or persistent skin ulcerations, especially if the patient has a history of diabetes.    

Option Analysis

✅ Plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial wound culture:
Incorrect: A culture from a superficial wound is unlikely to be helpful in the management of osteomyelitis. Cultures obtained from bone biopsy during surgery can make a definitive diagnosis and help with directing antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the foot :
Incorrect: CT is not as sensitive or specific as MRI for diagnosing osteomyelitis. It may be used in addition to plain films when MRI is not available or contraindicated. 
❌ Combined positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) of the foot:
Incorrect: PET/CT is effective in identifying osteomyelitis but is not widely used due to the cost, time-cost, and exposure to radiation. MRI is the study of choice for patients with suspected osteomyelitis, coupled with plain radiography.  
❌ Three-phase bone scintigraphy:
Incorrect: Three-phase bone scintigraphy is a nuclear medicine study that can be used to diagnose osteomyelitis when MRI is not available or contraindicated.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of right ankle pain that has progressively worsened over the past three weeks. He describes the pain as deep and constant and that it is occasionally sharp. He has not had recent trauma. He reports intermittent fevers, chills, and night sweats. He also notes increased swelling and redness over the right ankle over the past week. The patient has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes with a recent HbA1c of 9.2%. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The right ankle is erythematous, swollen, and tender to palpation with noticeable warmth. There is a small, non-healing ulcer on the plantar surface of the forefoot. There is a reduced range of motion of the foot due to pain, but there is no crepitus or obvious deformity. Pedal pulses are present but diminished. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the right foot and toes. Examination of the left foot reveals decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick but is otherwise normal. An X-ray of the ankle shows a lucent area in the distal tibia with surrounding periosteal reaction and no other bony deformities. Examination of the left foot and ankle is within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value      Result    
 Leukocyte count     15,000/µL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     50 mm/hr    
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     45 mg/L

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the ankle joint

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with progressive, subacute ankle pain; intermittent fevers; and night sweats along with the findings of a non-healing foot ulcer and peripheral neuropathy. Osteomyelitis is the most likely diagnosis, and the diagnosis is supported by the images showing a lucent area over the distal tibia with periosteal reaction and elevated inflammatory markers with white blood cell count on bloodwork.

When evaluating a patient with ankle pain, traumatic etiologies, such as fractures or sprains, should first be ruled out. When injury is present, The Ottawa ankle rules can be applied to determine the necessity of imaging to exclude an ankle fracture. In the absence of trauma, infectious causes like septic arthritis and osteomyelitis should be considered in patients with systemic symptoms, such as fever or a history of intravenous drug use or diabetes with ulcers. Blood tests, arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis, and imaging studies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can help determine if these conditions are present. In patients with diabetes, diabetic neuropathy should be considered, and testing with nerve conduction velocity studies along with imaging should be performed. Cases of suspected tendinopathies, osteoarthritis, or rheumatoid arthritis may require evaluation with X-rays, ultrasound, MRI, or joint aspiration.   

Option Analysis

❌ Septic arthritis of the ankle joint :
Incorrect: Patients with septic arthritis typically present with the acute onset of severe joint pain, swelling, and erythema—often accompanied by joint effusion and significantly limited range of motion. Early on, X-rays may be normal or show swelling and edema. The findings on X-ray of a lucent area and periosteal reaction indicate osteomyelitis. 
❌ Neuropathic arthropathy:
Incorrect: Neuropathic arthropathy, or Charcot joint, is characterized by joint deformity and lack of pain despite joint destruction. While this patient does have longstanding diabetes and evidence of peripheral neuropathy, the presence of fever and lack of deformity along with the imaging findings of lucency and periosteal reaction suggest osteomyelitis. 
❌ Achilles tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Achilles tendinopathy is associated with pain localized to the Achilles tendon that is made worse with dorsiflexion. It is caused by overuse. The findings of fever and ulceration and lucency and periosteal reaction on imaging are more consistent with osteomyelitis. 
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Patients with gout usually presents with acute onset of severe pain, erythema, and swelling of one or a few joints. It most commonly affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The findings of a non-healing ulcer and lucency and periosteal reaction on imaging are more suggestive of an osteomyelitis.  
✅ Osteomyelitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of severe left ankle pain and swelling and the inability to bear weight on the left foot for the past 24-hours. He has also been experiencing fevers and chills. There is no history of trauma. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Multiple track marks are present on the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to bear weight on the left foot. The left ankle is erythematous, swollen, warm, and tender to palpation with the presence of an effusion. The patient refuses to actively plantar or dorsiflex the foot as there is significant pain and limited range of motion with passive range of motion of the left ankle. Examination of the right ankle and foot is within normal limits. Which of the following tests will be most helpful for making a definitive diagnosis and guiding treatment?

choices.text: Complete blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the ankle

questions.solution:
This patient with a likely history of intravenous drug use (suggested by the multiple track marks present on physical exam) presents with severe left ankle pain, swelling, erythema, warmth, joint effusion, limited range of motion, and inability to bear weight. The most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid aspiration and analysis will be most helpful for confirming the diagnosis, ruling out other causes, such as crystal arthritis, and guiding treatment with tailored antibiotics. 

A thorough history and detailed physical examination should be used to create a differential diagnosis for a patient with ankle pain. Initially, traumatic causes, such as fractures or sprains, should be considered, especially in patients with a recent history of injury. The Ottawa ankle rules can be applied to determine the necessity of imaging to exclude fractures. In the absence of trauma, infectious causes like septic arthritis or osteomyelitis should be considered. This is particularly important in patients with systemic signs and symptoms, such as fever or chills, or with risk factors, like a history of intravenous drug use. These conditions can be confirmed with blood tests, synovial fluid analysis, and imaging (with MRI). If trauma and infection are unlikely but diabetes is present, then patients should be assessed for neuropathic pain with nerve conduction velocity studies. If tendinopathies, osteoarthritis, or systemic arthritis like rheumatoid arthritis is suspected, further evaluation with ultrasound, MRI, joint aspiration, and specific blood tests should be considered.   

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP) :
Incorrect: While an elevated white blood cell count or CRP may support the diagnosis of a joint infection (i.e. septic arthritis), they would not definitively identify the causative organism or confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ X-ray of the ankle:
Incorrect: An X-ray can help identify fractures or signs of osteomyelitis, but X-ray is not sensitive or specific enough for diagnosing septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the best test for diagnosing septic arthritis and guiding treatment. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the ankle:
Incorrect: MRI is useful for providing detailed imaging of the soft tissue and bone, but arthrocentesis would be better to confirm the diagnosis of septic arthritis and to guide the choice of antibiotics. 
❌ Nerve conduction velocity study:
Incorrect: Nerve conduction velocity studies are used to diagnose neuropathies. This patient's symptoms and history and physical examination findings are more indicative of septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the best test for confirming the diagnosis of septic arthritis and guiding treatment. 
✅ Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the emergency department for evaluation of a new limp. The patient has had fevers over the past 4 days and has been complaining of left groin pain. For the past day she has refused to walk and to move the left leg. The patient was ill with a viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI) one week ago but has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. The patient was born full-term, and vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 88/45 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. She is sitting in bed with the left hip flexed, slightly abducted, and externally rotated. Examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the left groin. She starts crying when the examiner attempts passive motion of the joint. The patient refuses to move the left leg and to bear weight on the left lower extremity. Which of the following findings is most concerning for a serious bacterial infection?

choices.text: Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of a limp with left hip and groin pain, fevers, and refusal to bear weight and move the leg. The fact that the patient is holding the leg flexed, slightly abducted, and externally rotated and refusing to walk along with the finding of pain with passive movement of the hip are concerning for septic arthritis of the hip.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different. Transient synovitis is a benign and self-limited illness, whereas septic arthritis requires drainage of the joint and antibiotics to prevent permanent bone, joint damage, and multisystem involvement. 

Pediatric patients with septic arthritis typically experience acute onset monoarticular joint pain and swelling (most commonly the knee, hip, or ankle), as well as systemic signs and symptoms, like fever, malaise, and decreased appetite. Most patients will demonstrate limited range of motion and refuse to walk on the affected limb. Infants and non-ambulatory children may display “pseudoparalysis,” which refers to the inability to move the affected joint due to pain. Patients are usually ill-appearing, with signs of erythema, warmth, and swelling of the skin overlying the affected joint.

Patients with transient synovitis typically present with monoarticular joint pain and swelling that usually affects the hip. Unlike constant joint pain seen with septic arthritis, joint pain with transient synovitis may wax and wane, and most patients will be afebrile or have a low-grade fever. Patients may show an improved range of motion soon after the use of NSAIDS. Most patients can bear weight on the affected extremity, though they may show a limp. History will often reveal a recent upper respiratory infection or episode of acute gastroenteritis. Physical examination typically reveals a well-appearing patient with possible joint effusion, in combination with limited range of motion of the affected joint due to pain.    

Option Analysis

✅ Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fever :
Incorrect: Both transient synovitis and septic arthritis can present with fevers. Generally, the fever in patients with septic arthritis is higher. However, it does not serve as a clear clinical differentiator between the two disorders. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ Limping:
Incorrect: Limping occurs in transient synovitis and septic arthritis. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ Monoarticular involvement:
Incorrect: Monoarticular involvement occurs in patients with transient synovitis and septic arthritis. This clinical feature cannot be used to distinguish the two conditions. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ History of recent URI:
Incorrect: History of a recent upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of transient synovitis as opposed to septic arthritis. Transient synovitis is usually a benign condition and is not secondary to a bacterial infection. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation of a limp. The parent reports that the symptoms were preceded by a cough and congestion one week ago. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 91/46 mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is comfortable and in no acute distress. There is limited range of motion at the right hip secondary to pain. He can bear weight on the lower right extremity. An ultrasound of the right hip demonstrates evidence of a moderate effusion. Blood work and arthrocentesis are obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin     12.8  g/dL     
 Leukocyte count     13,100/mm3     
 Platelet count     320,000/mm3     
 CRP     0.2 mg/dL     
 ESR     6 mm/h     
 Synovial fluid analysis     
 Gram stain, culture      Negative, no growth     
 Fluid      Clear, yellow          
 Cell count      6500 WBC/mm3
questions.solution:
Transient Synovitis 

This pediatric patient presents for assessment of right hip pain after a recent viral illness. He has multiple clinical features suggestive of transient synovitis. Blood work shows a mildly elevated white blood cell count and there is evidence of a moderate effusion on hip ultrasonography. Arthrocentesis of the hip involved demonstrates no evidence of septic arthritis with no growth on culture. The findings are consistent with transient synovitis which is typically self-limited and resolves on its own within 2 weeks. The initial recommended treatment for this condition involves rest and NSAIDs.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different.

If there is enough suspicion, formal diagnosis of septic arthritis and transient synovitis can be confirmed via joint aspiration, with evaluation of synovial fluid cell count with differential, gram stain, and culture. When children present with hip pain and there is concern for septic arthritis, arthrocentesis should be performed. In patients with septic arthritis, synovial fluid analysis will typically reveal bacterial growth, cloudy or purulent fluid, as well as a cell count > 50K WBC/mm3. These patients will also typically have positive blood cultures. In contrast, patients with transient synovitis will have a negative gram stain and culture, clear or yellow fluid, and a cell count of 5K - 15K WBC/mm3.

Treatment of septic arthritis involves empiric intravenous antibiotics based on the patient's age, clinical status, and risk factors. Antibiotics are tailored to the synovial fluid culture and sensitivity results. Arthrocentesis is both diagnostic and therapeutic and is necessary to decompress the joint space and remove inflammatory debris. Surgical consultation may be necessary for arthroscopic drainage or arthrotomy. In contrast, transient synovitis is managed conservatively, with treatment focused on pain control, rest, and supportive care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer ibuprofen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit for observation:
Incorrect: This patient has transient synovitis and there is no indication for observation. This patient can be discharged home. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Administer intraarticular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Administration of intraarticular glucocorticoids is not indicated in the treatment of transient synovitis. Administration of glucocorticoids can be considered for patients with juvenile idiopathic oligoarthritis. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation in patients with transient synovitis. 
❌ Consult orthopedics:
Incorrect: Orthopedic surgical consultation is indicated in the setting of septic arthritis, as these patients will typically require a washout of the joint space. This patient has transient synovitis, which does not require orthopedic consultation. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Administer nafcillin:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with transient synovitis. Antibiotics are not clinically indicated. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a three-day history of limping. Her parents report increased irritability and fatigue.
