She has no history of recent trauma but experienced an episode of pharyngitis one week ago that resolved without treatment. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 98 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The right thigh is swollen and warm to the touch. A radiograph reveals a small area of localized soft tissue swelling at the metaphysis of the right femur. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows bone marrow edema. Blood cultures are pending, and laboratory tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following would be expected on physical examination?

choices.text: Pain relief with passive movement of the limb
Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia
Well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb

questions.solution:
This 4-year-old girl presents with limping, irritability, and localized swelling and warmth of the right thigh. She is febrile and has elevated inflammatory markers. Radiography shows localized soft tissue swelling at the metaphysis of the right femur, and MRI reveals bone marrow edema. These findings are consistent with acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. The most supportive physical examination finding for this diagnosis is localized bony tenderness, rather than joint or soft tissue tenderness.        

In pediatric patients, osteomyelitis typically presents with fever, irritability, and a history of recent infection or trauma, although a clear preceding event may not always be identified. Affected children often exhibit limping, refusal to bear weight, or decreased use of the affected limb (pseudoparalysis), which may be the presenting symptom in nonverbal or younger patients. The physical examination commonly reveals localized swelling, warmth, tenderness, and sometimes erythema over the affected bone, with pain that persists even at rest. Osteomyelitis may also involve adjacent joints (septic arthritis) or present as a multifocal infection, necessitating a high index of suspicion for early diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pain relief with passive movement of the limb:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination, laboratory findings, and imaging are consistent with osteomyelitis, which causes severe pain that worsens with both passive and active movement of the affected limb. 
✅ Localized bony tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Appreciable joint effusion:
Incorrect: An appreciable joint effusion is more characteristic of septic arthritis, although in cases of hip involvement, the effusion might not be as apparent on physical exam. Septic arthritis of the hip often presents with severe pain with passive motion and when the hip is held in a flexed, externally rotated position. This patient’s imaging findings of bone marrow edema are more consistent with osteomyelitis, where localized bony tenderness is expected. 
❌ Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia:
Incorrect: Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia suggest a neurologic disorder, such as transverse myelitis or Guillain-Barré syndrome, which would not typically cause localized tenderness or warmth. This patient’s findings are consistent with osteomyelitis, and localized bony tenderness would be expected on examination. 
❌ Well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb :
Incorrect: A well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb is more characteristic of cellulitis, a soft tissue infection. This patient’s findings are more consistent with osteomyelitis, and localized bony tenderness would be expected on examination.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever and worsening right leg pain for the past five days. Her parent reports that she fell off her bicycle one week ago, scraping her right leg, but they did not seek medical attention at the time. Since then, she has been increasingly irritable, refusing to bear weight, and experiencing persistent leg pain even at rest. The patient’s temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg, heart rate is 135 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The right lower leg is swollen, warm, and tender to palpation, with limited range of motion due to pain. A scab is present over the right shin. Laboratory results are shown below. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right leg reveals bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess measuring 3.5 cm in diameter. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 White blood cell count     19,200/mm³   
 Hemoglobin     12.0 g/dL   
 Platelets     450,000/mm³   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     14.8 mg/dL   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     72 mm/hr

choices.text: Urgent surgical consultation for debridement and initiation of intravenous antibiotics
Needle aspiration of the abscess and delay antibiotics until culture results return
Empiric intravenous antibiotics with repeat MRI in 5–7 days to assess response
Empiric oral antibiotics for a 4–6-week course

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old girl with fever, worsening leg pain, refusal to bear weight, and a history of recent minor trauma presents with findings highly concerning for osteomyelitis with a subperiosteal abscess. An abscess larger than 2 cm requires urgent surgical drainage and intravenous (IV) antibiotics to prevent complications such as bone necrosis, chronic osteomyelitis, or sepsis.       

Treatment of pediatric osteomyelitis typically begins with empiric IV antibiotics targeting Staphylococcus aureus—the most common pathogen at this age—and other gram-positive organisms. Coverage is adjusted based on local methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) resistance patterns and culture results. If there is no abscess or the abscess is ≤ 2 cm, IV antibiotics alone are typically sufficient, with transition to oral antibiotics once clinical and laboratory improvement is observed. However, if MRI reveals an abscess > 2 cm or if there are red flags (e.g. no improvement after 48–72 hours of antimicrobial therapy), urgent surgical consultation for drainage or debridement is required to prevent progression to chronic osteomyelitis. In stable patients, initiation of empiric antibiotics will occasionally be delayed up to 24–48 hours until surgical intervention is performed and cultures are obtained. Serial measurements of inflammatory markers and clinical monitoring help guide treatment duration, and once improvement is noted, a prolonged course of oral antibiotics (typically 3–6 weeks) is necessary to ensure complete resolution.   



Option Analysis

❌ Empiric intravenous antibiotics with transition to oral antibiotics after 7 days :
Incorrect: Empiric intravenous antibiotics alone are appropriate for smaller abscesses (≤ 2 cm) or uncomplicated osteomyelitis but are insufficient for an abscess > 2 cm, which requires surgical drainage. Additionally, the transition to oral antibiotics is based on the patient’s clinical improvement rather than a fixed timeline. This patient requires surgical consultation for debridement in addition to initiation of empiric parenteral antibiotics.
✅ Urgent surgical consultation for debridement and initiation of intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle aspiration of the abscess and delay antibiotics until culture results return:
Incorrect: Delaying antibiotics while awaiting culture results in osteomyelitis with a significant abscess can lead to systemic spread or chronic infection. Although cultures should be obtained as part of the workup for osteomyelitis, empiric intravenous antibiotics should begin immediately.  
❌ Empiric intravenous antibiotics with repeat MRI in 5–7 days to assess response:
Incorrect: Although intravenous antibiotics are necessary in this case, surgical drainage is also required for the 3.5 cm abscess because an untreated abscess that is > 2 cm may progress and cause bone necrosis or chronic osteomyelitis. 
❌ Empiric oral antibiotics for a 4–6-week course:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for the initial management of osteomyelitis. This condition requires intravenous antibiotics initially, with a transition to oral therapy only after clinical and laboratory improvement. Additionally, an abscess > 2 cm also necessitates surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty walking. The patient’s parent states that, due to leg pain, the patient has been limping for the past two days, and today he refuses to walk. He has had fever, malaise, and poor oral intake over the past three days. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. He is up-to-date on vaccinations. Weight is 62nd percentile and height is 45th percentile. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 75/32 mmHg, pulse is 144/min, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing and uncomfortable. Examination of the right leg reveals an effusion of the right knee with overlying erythema and warmth. There is limited passive and active range of motion of the right knee due to pain. Examination of the left leg is normal. There are 2+ dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of progressively worsening right leg pain, and refusal to bear weight and ambulate. This, along with the associated fever and malaise as well as decreased range of motion of the right knee, with effusion, erythema, and warmth is consistent with septic arthritis. Based on the history, physical examination, and vital signs, the patient is unstable and septic. Therefore, the most important initial step in management is administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, with coverage of Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children, and Neisseria meningitidis. Vancomycin and cefepime are the appropriate antibiotic choices for pediatric patients with septic arthritis who are hemodynamically unstable. 

The acute management for unstable patients with septic arthritis centers on initial stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients should be given intravenous fluids and continuous vital sign monitoring. All unstable patients should receive intravenous empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, typically with a regimen that includes vancomycin with cefepime or vancomycin with ceftriaxone and Cefazolin, Nafcillin, or Oxacillin. Patients with sepsis who are unstable should be given immediate empiric antibiotics before arthrocentesis is performed, as a delay in antibiotic administration may be life-threatening. In contrast, stable patients should first have an arthrocentesis; and empiric antibiotics should be started while awaiting culture results. Antibiotic coverage for septic arthritis in hemodynamically stable patients depends on the patient’s age and risk factors. Patients should be covered for Staphylococcus aureus but may require additional coverage. For instance, if there is history of penetrating trauma, antibiotics should cover Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and if a patient is sexually active, antibiotics should cover Neisseria gonorrhea.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous vancomycin and cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient likely has septic arthritis and is hemodynamically unstable. Empiric treatment needs to cover for pathogens most likely to cause septic arthritis including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, and Neisseria meningitidis. The appropriate antibiotic regimen is vancomycin in addition to cefepime. 
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is not indicated in the treatment of septic arthritis. This patient requires empiric antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime. 
❌ Intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: This patient has septic arthritis and is hemodynamically unstable. Empiric treatment needs to cover for pathogens most likely to cause septic arthritis including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, and Neisseria meningitidis. The appropriate antibiotic regimen is vancomycin and cefepime. Clindamycin would be appropriate if the patient were hemodynamically stable and there was a high rate of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus in the community. 
❌ Intraarticular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Administration of intraarticular glucocorticoids is not indicated in the treatment of septic arthritis. Administration can be considered for patients with juvenile idiopathic oligoarthritis. This patient has a septic joint and requires empiric intravenous antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation of right leg pain. The patient had multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and low-grade fevers five days ago, which have fully resolved. However, over the past two days, the patient began complaining of right leg pain, and today he was limping. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Parents deny dysuria or hematuria. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/58 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress and is well-appearing. There is limited range of motion at the right hip secondary to pain, but active and passive movement is possible. There is no obvious erythema or warmth over the hip. All other joints are within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. Hip ultrasound shows an effusion. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin      12.5 g/dL     
 Leukocyte count      16,100/mm3     
 Platelet count      344,000/mm3     
 C-reactive protein (CRP)      1mg/dL     
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)      15 mm/h
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of right leg pain and limping and is found to have limited range of motion of the right hip due to pain. He has had a recent viral illness, which, along with the other clinical features, is suggestive of transient synovitis. Hip effusion is seen on ultrasound. Given that the patient has a white blood cell count over 15,500 and a slightly elevated c-reactive protein, he should have an arthrocentesis on this joint to formally rule out septic arthritis.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different. Transient synovitis is a benign and self-limited illness, whereas septic arthritis requires drainage of the joint and antibiotics to prevent permanent bone, joint damage, and multisystem involvement.

If there is enough suspicion, formal diagnosis of septic arthritis or transient synovitis is confirmed via joint aspiration, with evaluation of synovial fluid cell count with differential, gram stain, and culture. In patients with septic arthritis, synovial fluid analysis will typically reveal bacterial growth, cloudy or purulent fluid, as well as a cell count > 50K WBC/mm3. Patients can also have positive blood cultures. In contrast, patients with transient synovitis will have a negative gram stain and culture, clear or yellow fluid, and a cell count of 5K - 15K WBC/mm3.    

Option Analysis

✅ Perform hip arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order hip x-ray:
Incorrect: An x-ray of the hip may identify fracture, osteomyelitis, or other causes of pain and swelling, but is not the best next step in management. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, However, there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation of arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Order hip magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: An MRI may identify effusions or abnormalities of the bone and soft tissues, but it is not the best next step for this patient. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, but there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation with arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Order Borrelia burgorferi enzyme immunoassay (EIA) :
Incorrect: Lyme arthritis often presents as monoarthritis of the knee with effusion. This patient has an effusion in the hip and a history of recent gastrointestinal illness, making transient synovitis more likely. However, this patient has elevations in laboratory studies, making arthrocentesis the best next step to rule out septic arthritis. 
❌ Obtain urinalysis:
Incorrect: Urinalysis may be indicated if there is concern for reactive arthritis or urinary tract infection causing pelvic discomfort. This patient has an effusion in the hip and no urinary symptoms. This patient’s history is concerning for transient synovitis, but there is elevation of laboratory studies warranting further evaluation with arthrocentesis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever and lethargy. His parents report that he has been refusing to walk for the past two days and has become increasingly irritable. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, heart rate is 145 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, he appears ill and lethargic. The right thigh is swollen, warm, and tender to palpation. Laboratory results are displayed below, and blood cultures are pending. Radiographs of the femur reveal soft tissue swelling but no fracture or lytic lesions. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 White blood cell count     18,500/mm³   
 Hemoglobin     11.8 g/dL   
 Platelets     420,000/mm³   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     12.5 mg/dL   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     65 mm/hr

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right leg
Oral antibiotics with close outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old boy presents with fever, lethargy, worsening irritability, refusal to bear weight, and right thigh swelling, warmth, and tenderness—findings that are concerning for acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. Given the high clinical suspicion and the presence of systemic symptoms indicating potential deterioration, the best next step is to initiate empiric intravenous (IV) antibiotics.        

The acute management of osteomyelitis in pediatric patients depends on the patient's clinical stability. Unstable patients showing signs of sepsis require immediate IV fluid resuscitation and prompt administration of empiric IV antibiotics that target Staphylococcus aureus and other gram-positive organisms, followed by surgical consultation. For stable patients, the initial evaluation consists of laboratory tests (e.g., complete blood count, CRP, ESR, blood cultures) and imaging (e.g., radiographs, MRI). Depending on the evaluation results, treatment may involve starting IV antibiotics immediately, or if a surgical intervention is warranted, surgical consultation for aspirate or biopsy may be performed before initiating antibiotics.   

Option Analysis

❌ Needle aspiration and culture:
Incorrect: Although obtaining cultures is important to guide antibiotic therapy, the recommendation is to initiate empiric antibiotic treatment (ideally after blood cultures are collected) when there is clinical suspicion for osteomyelitis in a patient with worsening clinical status.
✅ Intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right leg:
Incorrect: MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for osteomyelitis. However, the clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are strongly indicative of osteomyelitis, justifying immediate treatment with empiric antibiotics. Delaying treatment for additional imaging is not advisable in this acutely ill child. 
❌ Oral antibiotics with close outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: Outpatient management with oral antibiotics is inappropriate for a child presenting with systemic signs of infection due to osteomyelitis. Hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics and close monitoring is required. 
❌ Contact child protective services:
Incorrect: While nonaccidental trauma should always be considered in young children with musculoskeletal complaints, this child's presentation is more consistent with an infectious process (osteomyelitis) rather than inflicted trauma. This patient should be admitted for intravenous antibiotics.       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a four-day history of fever and refusal to bear weight on his left leg. He has been increasingly irritable and reporting leg pain, even at rest. He has no history of recent trauma. The patient's temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 116 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is at the 35th percentile. On examination, the left thigh is swollen, warm, and tender along the femur, with no observable effusion in the right knee or thigh. The child refuses to move the leg. Laboratory results are shown below. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left leg is ordered. Which of the following imaging findings is most likely to be seen in this patient? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 White blood cell count     18,500/mm³   
 Hemoglobin     11.8 g/dL   
 Platelets     420,000/mm³   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     12.5 mg/dL   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     65 mm/hr

choices.text: Lytic lesion with surrounding bone sclerosis and bone marrow edema
Diffuse bone marrow edema and subperiosteal abscess
Well-demarcated osteonecrosis (double line sign) of the femoral head
Bone marrow edema with metaphyseal displacement

questions.solution:
This child presents with fever, refusal to bear weight, localized bony tenderness, and elevated inflammatory markers, all of which are highly suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting early osteomyelitis and is likely to show bone marrow edema, soft tissue swelling, and subperiosteal abscess formation (when an abscess is present).       

The diagnostic workup for osteomyelitis in pediatric patients begins with laboratory tests—including a complete blood count (CBC), CRP, ESR, and blood cultures—to assess inflammation and identify a causative organism. Plain radiographs are the initial imaging study to evaluate for periosteal reaction or cortical irregularities, although early findings may be absent. If clinical suspicion remains high despite negative radiographs, MRI is the next step, as it is the most sensitive test for detecting bone marrow edema, soft tissue swelling, and abscess formation. Bone aspiration or biopsy may be performed for culture and Gram stain to guide targeted antibiotic therapy.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lytic lesion with surrounding bone sclerosis and bone marrow edema:
Incorrect: A lytic lesion with surrounding bone sclerosis and bone marrow edema is more suggestive of a bone tumor—specifically, an osteoid osteoma. In contrast, this patient presents with fever, swelling, warmth, and tenderness over the femur, which supports a diagnosis of osteomyelitis. Therefore, an MRI would more likely reveal diffuse bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess.
✅ Diffuse bone marrow edema and subperiosteal abscess :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Well-demarcated osteonecrosis (double line sign) of the femoral head:
Incorrect: Well-demarcated osteonecrosis of the femoral head is characteristic of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which typically presents with a limp, minimal pain (if any), and progressive hip dysfunction rather than fever and systemic inflammation. This patient’s history and physical examination are more consistent with osteomyelitis, which can show diffuse bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess on MRI.
❌ Hip effusion with synovial inflammation:
Incorrect: Hip effusion with synovial inflammation is a nonspecific finding in toxic synovitis or septic arthritis of the hip. This patient exhibits localized tenderness over the femur, and the overall clinical picture favors osteomyelitis. MRI in osteomyelitis may reveal diffuse bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess. 
❌ Bone marrow edema with metaphyseal displacement:
Incorrect: Bone marrow edema with metaphyseal displacement is seen in patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), a condition that typically occurs in adolescents with obesity and presents with leg pain and altered gait. In contrast, this patient shows signs of infection, and the history and physical examination are consistent with osteomyelitis. MRI findings in osteomyelitis may include diffuse bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for osteomyelitis of the right ankle due to Staphylococcus aureus. Medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease stage two and myelodysplastic syndrome. On admission, the patient was started on an antibiotic that directly inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis. While rounding on the patient on hospital day seven, he mentioned tinnitus and hearing loss which began over the last 24 hours. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 96% on room air. Physical examination shows bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal. Which of the following additional adverse effects is this patient at risk for if this antibiotic is continued long-term?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with staphylococcal osteomyelitis and has now developed auditory symptoms. This presentation is suggestive of vancomycin-induced ototoxicity.

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent that inhibits bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is indicated in the empiric treatment of osteomyelitis and third-generation cephalosporin. Treatment with this combination covers methicillin-resistant S. aureus (by vancomycin) and most gram-negative organisms (by ceftriaxone).

Vancomycin is associated with adverse effects, which include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, thrombophlebitis and red man syndrome (flushing and pruritus due to the infusion of vancomycin) and DRESS syndrome (drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms). Significant renal injury – as evidenced by an acute drop in urine output or a significant rise in serum creatinine – is an indication to reduce the dose of vancomycin or switch to a different antibiotic.  

Option Analysis

❌ Neuromuscular blockade:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides can cause neuromuscular blockade, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. They are bactericidal agents that inhibit bacterial protein synthesis; they do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is associated with using agents such as chloramphenicol, zidovudine, and TMP-SMX. None of these agents are known to cause ototoxicity, and they do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and should be avoided in patients above 60 or those taking prednisone. They do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis or cause ototoxicity.  
❌ Seizures:
Incorrect: Carbapenems inhibit PBPs/transpeptidases that cause cross-linking in bacterial cell wall synthesis. CNS toxicity (myoclonus, seizures, and altered mental status) is associated with carbapenem use (especially imipenem). Carbapenems do not usually cause ototoxicity and would not be used to treat S. aureus osteomyelitis.  
✅ Acute reduction in urine output:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is evaluated for muscle weakness and a 5-kg (11-lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 4 months. In addition, the patient frequently wakes up at night due to coughing and finds himself covered in sweat. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia, for which he currently takes atorvastatin. Social history is notable for a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 122/73 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination is notable for 4/5 strength in the proximal arms and legs. Swelling and a purplish-red discoloration is observed on the bilateral eyelids. During the visit, the patient frequently coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Obtain serum TSH and T3/T4 levels
Perform muscle biopsy of the quadriceps

questions.solution:
This patient has dermatomyositis, likely secondary to an underlying lung malignancy. Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune antibody-mediated condition that presents with proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings. These include Gottron papules, heliotrope rash (which was observed on this patient’s examination), shawl and face rash, and mechanic hands (hyperkeratotic, scaling, and fissuring of the patient’s hands).  

Dermatomyositis is associated with malignancies such as Hodgkin lymphoma as well as lung, stomach, colorectal, and ovarian cancer. In this vignette, the patient’s symptoms of cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss in combination with his smoking history raise concerns for a lung malignancy. If an underlying malignancy is suspected, additional testing such as x-ray or CT should be ordered.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain serum TSH and T3/T4 levels:
Incorrect: Measurements of serum TSH and T3/T4 levels are necessary in the work-up hypothyroidism. This condition can cause myopathy and muscle weakness. However, hypothyroidism typically causes an increase in body weight. Moreover, it would be atypical for hypothyroidism to cause the cough and night sweats experienced by this patient.
❌ Obtain peripheral blood eosinophil count:
Incorrect: A peripheral blood eosinophil count can be ordered as part of the work-up for eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome). The condition can present with pulmonary syndromes (e.g., sinusitis, asthma) and cutaneous findings (e.g., nodules, purpura). However, it would be atypical for the condition to present with proximal muscle weakness or night sweats.
❌ Perform muscle biopsy of the quadriceps:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is highly characteristic of dermatomyositis. He has symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and skin findings consistent with a heliotrope rash. As a result, a muscle biopsy is unnecessary to confirm the diagnosis. Instead, additional testing should be performed to evaluate for an underlying malignancy, especially given the patient’s night sweats and unintentional weight loss, since dermatomyositis is associated with malignancy. 
❌ Discontinue atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Statin-associated myopathy can present with muscle pain and weakness. Discontinuation of the medication can prevent side-effect exacerbation and progression to rhabdomyolysis. However, statin-associated myopathy would not account for the patient’s heliotrope rash, chronic cough, or unintentional weight loss.
✅ Order a chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is evaluated by the primary care physician for 9-weeks of muscle pain and joint stiffness most prominent in the bilateral hips and shoulders. The patient reports that the symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with movement. He has had no headaches, jaw pain, or vision loss. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he is currently taking diltiazem. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 133/79 mmHg, pulse is 66/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. On physical exam, the bilateral deltoids and quadriceps are tender to palpation. No muscle weakness is observed. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  

 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.8 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  8,800/mm3 
 Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)   98 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  81 U/L 

What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has polymyalgia rheumatica, an inflammatory disease that most often affects individuals over 50 years of age. The condition can be diagnosed using a combination of the patient’s history, physical examination, and laboratory results.

The condition typically causes symptoms like pain and stiffness of the shoulders and hips. The symptoms are generally more severe in the morning and at night, often lasting for more than an hour, and they typically improve after activity. Polymyalgia rheumatica can also cause a low-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite, which can lead to weight loss.  

Laboratory testing will reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) level. There is little damage to muscles, so serum creatinine kinase levels are within normal limits. In contrast, conditions such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis that cause muscle damage will present with elevated creatinine kinase levels.    

Patients diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica should be started on low-dose corticosteroids such as prednisolone. The response to corticosteroids is rapid, and most patients have symptomatic improvement after the first week of treatment. In fact, PMR is so responsive to steroid therapy that a lack of improvement warrants investigation of a different diagnosis. In addition, exercise and a healthy diet can strengthen muscles and bones as well as improve flexibility in the joints affected by the disease.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate low-dose oral prednisolone therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Initiate daily NSAID therapy:
Incorrect: NSAID therapy is useful in conditions related to joint inflammation, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), or ankylosing spondylitis. Although RA may present similarly with morning stiffness that improves with movement, this patient’s muscle tenderness, elevated ESR, and low-grade fevers are suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica, which requires a different form of treatment. 
❌ Perform temporal artery biopsy:
Incorrect: A temporal artery biopsy can be used to diagnose patients with temporal arteritis. The condition can cause headaches, jaw pain, and vision loss. The patient’s symptoms raise concern for polymyalgia rheumatica, which increases the risk of developing temporal arteritis. However, the patient has no symptoms specific to temporal arteritis, and thus a biopsy is not warranted at this time.
❌ Perform quadriceps muscle biopsy:
Incorrect: A proximal muscle biopsy is used to diagnose patients with dermatomyositis or polymyositis. Both of these conditions present with proximal muscle tenderness. Individuals with these conditions also have muscle weakness. In contrast, this patient has full strength. Moreover, individuals with these conditions have an elevated creatinine kinase, whereas this patient’s value is normal.
❌ Initiate imipramine therapy:
Incorrect: Tricyclic antidepressants are used to treat fibromyalgia. The condition can present with widespread pain, fatigue, muscle stiffness, and difficulty concentrating (“fibro fog”). In contrast, this patient presents with localized pain most prominent in the shoulders and hips. Moreover, fibromyalgia would not cause an elevated ESR.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for generalized fatigue and soft-tissue pain that began 5 months ago. She reports the pain being present in all of her muscles. The patient feels tired every morning despite getting adequate sleep and is having a hard time concentrating at her job as an attorney. Past medical history is notable for depression that was successfully treated with bupropion. She is currently not taking any medications. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength and full range-of-motion in the upper and lower extremities. Soft-tissue tenderness is elicited at multiple locations across the patient’s body. The patient is started on an aerobic-exercise regimen. At her follow-up appointment in 6-weeks, the patient reports no improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Initiate selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
This patient has fibromyalgia. Patients with fibromyalgia present with chronic widespread pain that most often presents at points where muscles attach to the bone.

Diagnosis of fibromyalgia is based on a few factors. First, the diagnosis can be made if there is pain in at least seven or more areas of the body, termed “tender points,” with a symptoms severity scale score of at least five points out of a possible twelve. The symptoms severity scale gives points for a wide range of symptoms from difficulty concentrating and remembering things—sometimes called “fibro fog”—to fatigue and unrefreshing sleep. Alternatively, the diagnosis can be made if there is pain in at least five or more areas of the body, with a symptoms severity score of at least nine points out of a possible twelve. Additionally, the symptoms need to be present for at least 3 months.  

Treatment of fibromyalgia requires a holistic approach. Cardiovascular exercise can help by reducing pain and fatigue. Relaxation techniques and good sleep hygiene can also help. If these approaches fail, medications can be used. Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, are the first-line therapy. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) can be used in instances where the first-line therapy is not effective.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy:
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are involved in the treatment of fibromyalgia. However, they are not the first-line medication, which are tricyclic antidepressants. Instead, SSRIs should be administered to patients with cases of fibromyalgia that do not adequately improve with first-line therapy.   
❌ Initiate low-dose corticosteroid therapy:
Incorrect: Low-dose steroid therapy is used in the treatment of inflammatory conditions such as polymyalgia rheumatica. This condition presents with pain and stiffness predominantly in the shoulders and hips. In contrast, this patient has diffuse pain as well as difficulty concentrating at work. Additionally, polymyalgia rheumatica almost exclusively presents in adults over the age of 50. This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with the presentation of fibromyalgia, and steroids are not indicated in the treatment of this condition. 
❌ Referral for psychiatric evaluation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has fibromyalgia, which is not a psychiatric condition. There is no need for the patient to seek additional care from a psychiatrist. 
✅ Initiate tricyclic antidepressant therapy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Perform proximal muscle biopsy:
Incorrect: A proximal muscle biopsy can be used to diagnose patients with dermatomyositis or polymyositis. Both of these conditions can present with proximal muscle tenderness and muscle weakness. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has diffuse tenderness and intact strength on physical examination.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. He has not seen a doctor in several years. Over the past few years, he has gradually developed worsening weakness in the hands, forearms, and legs. He has trouble getting out of a chair and also trouble opening bottles and jars. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Vital signs are unremarkable. He appears frail. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left forearm muscles, 4/5 in the right forearm, 3/5 in the right hip and quadricep, and 4/5 in the left hip and quadricep. Weakness of the distal finger flexor muscles is also noted. A random muscle biopsy shows inflammatory cells with vacuolated muscle fibers and amyloid deposits. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with the insidious onset of asymmetrical muscle weakness of the forearms, legs, and distal finger flexor muscles and inflammatory cells and vacuolated muscle fibers on muscle biopsy consistent with a diagnosis of inclusion body myositis (IBM). Unlike most other inflammatory myopathies, inclusion body myositis is unresponsive to immunosuppressive agents. Treatment of inclusion body myositis consists of physical, occupational, and speech therapy aimed at preserving functional capacity.

Patients with inclusion body myositis typically present with asymmetrical weakness involving the proximal leg muscles and distal forearm muscles. Involvement of the distal finger flexor muscles is characteristic for the condition. The skin is not typically involved. Myositis-specific antibodies may be positive and muscle biopsy shows inflammatory cells, rimmed vacuolated muscle fibers, and intracellular amyloid deposits.

Treatment of most inflammatory myopathies, including dermatomyositis and polymyositis, centers around the use of glucocorticoids and disease modifying anti-rheumatologic drugs (DMARDs), such as azathioprine and methotrexate; other immunosuppressive agents may be used as well. DMARDs can also be used as steroid-sparing therapy in patients with difficulty tapering off steroids and if steroid side effects are present.

Unlike dermatomyositis and polymyositis, IBM responds poorly to immunosuppressive medications. As such, the primary goal of therapy for IBM is to optimize muscle strength and function. Treatment is centered around preserving functional capacity through physical, occupational, and speech therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ Physical therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are used to treat most inflammatory myopathies (e.g. dermatomyositis, polymyositis); however, this patient with inflammatory cells and vacuolated muscle fibers and amyloid deposits on muscle biopsy has inclusion body myositis, which does not respond to glucocorticoids.  
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG):
Incorrect: IVIG can be used to treat immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy. However, this patient with inflammatory cells and vacuolated muscle fibers and amyloid deposits on muscle biopsy has inclusion body myositis for which IVIG is not used as treatment.  
❌ Azathioprine:
Incorrect: Disease modifying anti-rheumatologic drugs (DMARDs), such as azathioprine and methotrexate, are typically used to treat dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, this patient with inflammatory cells and vacuolated muscle fibers on muscle biopsy has inclusion body myositis for which DMARDs are not appropriate treatment.  
❌ Rituximab:
Incorrect: Rituximab may be used to treat resistant dermatomyositis and polymyositis or immune-mediated necrotizing myositis. However, this patient with inflammatory cells and vacuolated muscle fibers and amyloid deposits on muscle biopsy has inclusion body myositis, which is typically unresponsive to immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for generalized weakness and a new rash. Over the past month, the patient has become fatigued much more easily when walking, gardening, and brushing her hair. The patient has also developed pink-purple discoloration over both eyelids and in a V-shape over the anterior neck and chest. She has no fever, chills, dysphagia, chest pain, shortness of breath, or orthopnea. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are unremarkable. A physical examination is performed, showing 3/5 muscle strength in the proximal upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated creatine kinase of 2800 U/L and the presence of anti-Mi-2 antibodies. Which of the following physical examination findings, if present, would be a specific indication of the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pink-Violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the fingers
Thin tight skin on the fingers
Hyperkeratosis and fissuring of the palms and lateral fingers

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash (pink-violaceous rash on the eyelids), and a V-sign (pink-violaceous rash on the anterior neck and chest) most likely has dermatomyositis. Pink-violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the bony prominences of the fingers, referred to as Gottron papules, are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.

Inflammatory myopathies are a group of conditions that result in progressive muscle weakness. These include dermatomyositis, antisynthetase syndrome, immune-mediated necrotizing myositis, inclusion body myositis, and polymyositis. A thorough history and physical examination can help pinpoint a particular diagnosis, and autoantibodies and muscle biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

History may reveal signs of progressive proximal muscle weakness, such as in the shoulders and pelvic girdle muscles in dermatomyositis and polymyositis. For example, patients may describe difficulty combing their hair or standing up from a chair. Patients with inclusion body myositis may have both proximal and distal muscle weakness that is asymmetric. Patients with inflammatory myopathies may have associated rashes or findings such as shortness of breath (from pulmonary fibrosis) or difficulty swallowing. The presence of a rash can be used to distinguish dermatomyositis from polymyositis. Patients may have a family history of rheumatologic diseases. Physical examination should be used to assess muscle strength and to determine if weakness is symmetric or asymmetric and predominantly proximal or distal. A careful skin examination is necessary to look for associated rash. Patients with dermatomyositis may have a heliotrope rash, V-sign, rash on the posterior shoulders (shawl sign), and Gottron papules.
 

Fig 1. Gottron papules (reference: Ricceri F, Prignano F. Gottron papules: a pathognomonic sign of dermatomyositis. CMAJ. 2013 Feb 5;185(2):148. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.111791. Epub 2012 Jul 23. PMID: 22825999; PMCID: PMC3563888.)  

Option Analysis

✅ Pink-Violaceous papules on the dorsal aspects of the fingers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fine inspiratory crackles:
Incorrect: Fine inspiratory crackles can be seen in autoimmune diseases that are associated with pulmonary fibrosis, such as scleroderma and antisynthetase syndrome. Pulmonary fibrosis can be seen in dermatomyositis, but it is not an indicator of dermatomyositis since it can be seen with many rheumatic conditions.  
❌ Thin tight skin on the fingers:
Incorrect: Sclerodactyly (or thin tight skin) can occur in immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy but is not generally seen in other inflammatory myopathies. It is also a prominent feature of scleroderma and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome). Gottron papules are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.  
❌ Swollen tender joints:
Incorrect: Arthritis can be seen in antisynthetase syndrome as well as many other rheumatologic diseases. It rarely may be seen in dermatomyositis, and it does not specifically indicate dermatomyositis when it is present as it can be seen with many rheumatologic conditions.  
❌ Hyperkeratosis and fissuring of the palms and lateral fingers:
Incorrect: This finding, referred to as “Mechanic’s hands,” can be seen in both dermatomyositis and antisynthetase syndrome. It does not specifically indicate dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a two-month history of worsening shortness of breath. Additionally over the past two months, she has experienced intermittent low-grade fevers, diffuse muscle weakness and pain, and swelling of the joints of her hands. She has no dysphagia or changes in the color of her fingers with exposure to cold. She has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension for which she takes metformin and carvedilol, respectively. Temperature is 37.8ºC (100.0ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 131/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 94% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral basilar inspiratory crackles. Examination of the hands shows bilateral hyperkeratosis, fissures, and scaling on the radial aspect of the fingers along with swelling of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints. There are no ulcerations on the fingertips. Muscle exam shows 3/5 strength in the shoulders and hips bilaterally with 5/5 strength of the distal muscles. There are no other rashes and no skin thickening on the rest of the hands, forearms, or trunk. Muscle biopsy shows perimysial inflammation with muscle fiber degeneration. Which of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents acutely with low-grade fever, shortness of breath, muscle weakness, arthritis with bilateral inspiratory crackles, low O2 saturation, and mechanic’s hands on physical examination. This constellation of findings is highly suggestive of antisynthetase syndrome. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are typically present in patients with antisynthetase syndrome.

Inflammatory myopathies are a group of conditions that result in progressive muscle weakness; these include dermatomyositis, antisynthetase syndrome, immune-mediated necrotizing myositis, inclusion body myositis, and polymyositis. A thorough history and physical examination can help pinpoint a particular diagnosis; for example, proximal muscle weakness is typically seen in patients with dermatomyositis and polymyositis, while distal asymmetric muscle weakness is more often seen in patients with inclusion body myositis.

Increased creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) can be seen with myopathy, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are typically normal or mildly elevated. A combination of autoantibody testing and muscle biopsy findings can be used to determine the specific diagnosis. Skin biopsy can be used to differentiate dermatomyositis from polymyositis. Chest radiography and pulmonary function tests (PFTs) with diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide should be performed for all patients with suspected or confirmed dermatomyositis (DM) or polymyositis (PM), regardless of pulmonary symptoms. High resolution computed tomography (CT) scan should be performed for all patients with cough or dyspnea, findings consistent with interstitial lung disease on physical exam, or antisynthetase antibodies.

The table below lists the associated antibodies and muscle biopsy findings for each type of inflammatory myopathy.
 
 

Figure 1. Mechanic’s Hands

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-Jo-1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-Mi-2:
Incorrect: Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are associated with dermatomyositis. While mechanic’s hands can also be seen in dermatomyositis, the lack of other rashes and the presence of fever, findings consistent with interstitial lung disease, and arthritis in this patient are more suggestive of antisynthetase syndrome.  
❌ Anti-SRP:
Incorrect: Anti-SRP is associated with immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy. This patient’s muscle biopsy does not show findings of necrotic and regenerating muscle fibers that would indicate immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy.  
❌ Anti-Scl-70:
Incorrect: Anti-Scl-70 is associated with scleroderma (systemic sclerosis). This patient’s mechanic’s hands and myopathy (inflammatory findings on muscle biopsy) are not suggestive of scleroderma. This patient has no evidence of skin thickening or dysphagia that would suggest an overlap syndrome with scleroderma.  
❌ Anti-histone:
Incorrect: Anti-histone is associated with drug-induced lupus. While lupus can present with many different symptoms that overlap with inflammatory myopathies, this patient does not take medications that would cause drug-induced lupus (e.g. hydralazine, procainamide).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought for a well-child evaluation after recent immigration into the country. The child began walking unsupported at 23 months of age but is still unable to climb up the stairs without help from his parents. He can draw a circle but cannot catch a ball. The patient has a vocabulary of more than 200 words and can combine them in three-word phrases. He can eat independently and knows his age and gender. The mother’s pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 32 weeks. There is no family history of developmental delays or motor disorders. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 92/63 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination no dysmorphic features are noted. Neurologic, cardiopulmonary, and abdominal exams are normal. Which of the following best describes this child’s developmental status?
questions.solution:
The child in the vignette is exhibiting isolated gross motor delay most likely secondary to prematurity (with birth at 32 weeks gestational age). Red flags that can signal motor delay in a three-year-old include difficulty using stairs and inability to catch a ball.  

When assessing development milestones in a child, it is important to understand normal development. At three-years, a child is expected to walk upstairs with alternating feet, pedal a tricycle and catch a ball. In the area of language and communication, a three-year-old should have a vocabulary of over 200 words, make three-word sentences, and have about 75% of their speech understood by strangers. Self-help skills appropriate for this age include eating independently, toilet training, and putting on their own shoes. They should be able to identify their age and gender, take turns and enjoy imaginative play.

Pediatric patients with gross motor delays should be evaluated for neuromuscular disorders. Prematurity and low birth weight are known risk factors for developmental delays. Cerebral palsy may be diagnosed in patients with a history of hypoxic ischemic insults, central nervous system infections, stroke, or kernicterus. A positive family history can suggest genetic or metabolic disorders. In patients with a history of prematurity and gross motor delays, if the physical exam also reveals low to normal tone or weakness, brain imaging should be performed to rule out other causes like cerebral palsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Gross motor delay:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Global developmental delay:
Incorrect: Global developmental delay is present when two or more of the major categories show delay. This child shows appropriate language and cognitive skills but is exhibiting isolated gross motor delay.
❌ Cognitive delay:
Incorrect: Cognitive delay in a three-year-old is characterized by difficulties with tasks such as independent eating, putting on shoes or understanding comparisons. This patient does not exhibit any difficulties with these tasks. Therefore, cognitive delay is unlikely.
❌ Language delay:
Incorrect: Given the child's vocabulary of more than 200 words and ability to form three-word phrases, language development appears to be age-appropriate for this three-year-old.
❌ Social-emotional delay:
Incorrect: This patient knows his age and gender and seems to be showing appropriate social and emotional development.

questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at term is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) at 2 days of life due to feeding difficulties and choking episodes. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. The mother takes pyridostigmine for a chronic disorder but was asymptomatic throughout pregnancy. The infant has poor sucking during breastfeeding. Weight is 2900 g. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 70/38 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the newborn demonstrates a weak cry, bilateral ptosis, and generalized hypotonia with preserved reflexes. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Complete blood count (CBC), C-reactive protein, and creatinine kinase (CK) are within normal limits. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies (NCS) demonstrate a decremental response of the compound muscle action potential with repetitive nerve stimulation. Which of the following findings is expected in the laboratory evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn with a maternal history of likely myasthenia gravis (treated with pyridostigmine), feeding difficulties, poor sucking, ptosis, and generalized hypotonia has transient neonatal myasthenia gravis (MG). Diagnosis is supported by detection of anti-acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR) antibodies.       

Neonatal hypotonia may result from systemic illness or dysfunction of the central or peripheral nervous system. An alert infant who responds appropriately to the surroundings but with profound weakness raises concern for a peripheral nervous system etiology. Normal CK levels argue against primary myopathy. In this context, EMG/NCS demonstrating a decremental response to low-frequency repetitive stimulation suggests a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder.        

Fluctuating weakness, a maternal history of MG, and seropositivity for anti-AChR antibodies support a diagnosis of transient neonatal myasthenia gravis (MG). In contrast, congenital MG results from mutations such as those in the CHRNE gene. A positive response to an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor would be expected. Botulism, another NMJ disorder, presents with descending paralysis and is associated with Clostridium botulinum exposure (e.g. honey ingestion), often confirmed by stool culture or direct toxin assay.   

Option Analysis

❌ Positive direct toxin assay  :
Incorrect: Infantile botulism is confirmed with a positive toxin assay, typically following ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores (e.g. in honey). However, this neonate is only 2 days old with no exposure history. The presentation and maternal history are more consistent with neonatal myasthenia gravis, which can be confirmed with anti-AChR antibodies. 
❌ Positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) :
Incorrect: A positive ANA may be seen in neonatal lupus, which typically presents with heart block and cutaneous lesions. This presentation and maternal history are more consistent with neonatal myasthenia gravis, which can be confirmed with anti-AChR antibodies. 
✅ Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR) antibodies :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated thyroid stimulating hormone levels  :
Incorrect: Congenital hypothyroidism may cause hypotonia and feeding difficulties but often presents with additional signs (e.g., macroglossia, umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice). The maternal history, clinical picture, and EMG/NCS findings in this case point to neonatal myasthenia gravis. 
❌ Positive blood culture  :
Incorrect: Neonatal sepsis can present with hypotonia and poor feeding, but this patient is afebrile and has normal inflammatory markers and blood counts. The maternal history, clinical picture, and EMG/NCS findings in this case point to neonatal myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of poor sucking, difficulty feeding, and lethargy for the past three hours. The caregiver reports feeding the infant honey last week. There is no history of fever, rash, vomiting, or seizures. Immunizations are up to date. Birth, medical, and family histories are unremarkable. Development is appropriate for age. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 57/min, blood pressure is 77/42 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. The infant exhibits symmetrical hypotonia, diminished sucking, and drooping eyelids. Increased work of breathing with grunting is noted. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

          Capillary blood gas          
 pH     7.32    
 PCO2     58 mmHg    
 PO2     60 mmHg    
 HCo3      22 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This infant presents with poor sucking, difficulty feeding, lethargy, hypotonia, and respiratory failure following honey ingestion; these findings are consistent with infantile botulism. Blood gas analysis shows respiratory acidosis, and emergent intubation with mechanical ventilation is required to stabilize the airway and support breathing.   

In pediatric patients, hypotonia may result from disorders of the neuromuscular junction, including transient neonatal myasthenia gravis, congenital myasthenia, and infantile botulism. Infantile botulism is caused by ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores, which can be found in honey. Affected infants typically develop hypotonia, constipation, lethargy, and poor feeding several days after exposure. Physical examination reveals a “floppy baby” with head lag, ptosis, weak cry, and signs of descending paralysis. Diagnosis is confirmed by detection of botulinum toxin or organism in stool, serum, or gastric contents.       

All infants presenting with hypotonia should undergo an ABCDE assessment. In infantile botulism, diaphragmatic weakness can lead to rapid progression to respiratory failure, as seen in this case. Early airway protection with intubation and mechanical ventilation is essential. Once stabilized, management includes supportive care and administration of botulism immune globulin. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and supplemental oxygen, if needed, is part of ongoing treatment.   

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Electromyography (EMG)  :
Incorrect: EMG can help confirm the diagnosis of neuromuscular disorders in patients presenting with hypotonia. However, this infant has respiratory acidosis and clinical signs of respiratory failure. Stabilizing the airway and breathing takes precedence over diagnostic testing. 
❌ Direct stool toxin assay :
Incorrect: Stool toxin testing can confirm the diagnosis of infantile botulism. However, this infant has significant respiratory compromise, requiring immediate airway management. Diagnostic confirmation should not delay life-saving interventions.  
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine :
Incorrect: Spinal MRI is used to evaluate hypotonia with ascending weakness in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome. This patient’s presentation following honey ingestion is more consistent with infantile botulism. Regardless, respiratory compromise must be addressed first. 
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics are used in cases of suspected sepsis, typically characterized by fever and hemodynamic instability. In this case, the clinical picture and exposure history are more consistent with infantile botulism, and immediate airway support is required.

questions.text: A 6‐year‐old boy presents to the clinic with a caregiver due to repeated falls over the past three months. The caregiver reports recent fatigue while playing sports and difficulty climbing stairs, along with poor head control since infancy. There is no history of muscle pain, trauma, fever, rash, or recent travel. Family history reveals a maternal uncle with similar symptoms who is now bedridden. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient demonstrates a waddling gait and 2/5 strength in lower extremity muscles, with hypotonia and hyporeflexia. The child walks his hands up his legs to stand up from the floor. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following physical exam findings is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child presents with progressive muscle weakness (including poor head control since infancy), a positive family history, and Gower sign (i.e. walking his hands up his legs to stand up from the floor, a characteristic sign of proximal muscle weakness). These findings are characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is also associated with calf pseudohypertrophy on physical examination.        

The evaluation of hypotonia begins with a thorough history and physical exam. Important historical features include motor delays, developmental regression, feeding or respiratory difficulties, and any family history of neuromuscular or genetic conditions. On exam, assess tone, strength, reflexes, and developmental responsiveness. The presence of weakness, hyporeflexia, and muscle atrophy should prompt evaluation for muscle disease.       

Initial testing includes serum creatine kinase (CK) and electromyography (EMG). A normal CK suggests congenital myopathy. An elevated CK raises concern for muscular dystrophies such as DMD, congenital myotonic dystrophy, congenital muscular dystrophy, or Pompe disease. Muscular dystrophies are inherited progressive myopathic disorders caused by defects in genes essential for normal muscle function.       

DMD is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, which encodes dystrophin. It primarily affects biological males, and there is often a positive family history. Clinical findings include progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gower sign, and calf pseudohypertrophy. Diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing for DMD mutations.    

Option Analysis

✅ Calf pseudohypertrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatomegaly  :
Incorrect: Hepatomegaly is seen in Pompe disease and may occur alongside hypotonia, muscle weakness and wasting, and macroglossia. Progressive muscle weakness, a positive family history, and Gower sign are more consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. 
❌ Hypogonadism  :
Incorrect: Hypogonadism is seen in syndromes such as Prader-Willi, which typically presents with hypotonia in infancy, along with obesity, hyperphagia, and cognitive impairment. Progressive muscle weakness, a positive family history, and Gower sign are more consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.  
❌ Microcephaly  :
Incorrect: Patients with brain malformations may initially present with hypotonia, but typically develop hypertonia, global developmental delay, and either microcephaly or macrocephaly. Progressive muscle weakness, a positive family history, and Gower sign are more consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is also associated with calf hypertrophy. 
❌ Ptosis  :
Incorrect: Ptosis can be associated with neuromuscular junction disorders such as myasthenia gravis, which can cause fluctuating weakness. Progressive muscle weakness, a positive family history, and Gower sign are more consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is also associated with calf hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic because of left eye pain and dryness that has progressed throughout the day. His eye felt irritated when he awoke this morning, but he has not noticed redness or discharge from the eye. With repeated checks in the mirror, he has also noticed that the left side of his mouth is drooping compared to the right and his left brow does not furrow as much as the right. His hearing is intact bilaterally, and he has no ear pain or tinnitus. He has had no recent travel, immunizations, or new medications and resides in Arizona, United States. He has been under significant stress at work. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. There is no conjunctival erythema or discharge. Pupils are equally reactive and round. There is decreased tear production. He is unable to fully close his left eye. There is flattening of the left nasolabial fold. The left pinna, external ear canal, and tympanic membrane (TM) appear normal. Which of the following additional historical or physical examination findings would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Tingling in both feet and areflexia

questions.solution:
This patient presents with left eye pain and dryness and a left-sided facial droop. He is unable to fully close the eyelid and raise the eyebrow on the left, indicating lower motor neuron involvement of cranial nerve VII, which is a peripheral cause of facial paralysis. Bell palsy, also known as idiopathic peripheral facial palsy, is the most common cause of facial paralysis and is likely the cause of this patient’s symptoms given his lack of history or findings specific to another condition. Symptoms in Bell palsy are isolated to the head, and no other neurologic deficits indicating a systemic or central neurologic cause should be present.         

A focused history and physical examination will guide the evaluation and management of facial paralysis. Forehead involvement is indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion, or peripheral cause. The patient may describe a history of sudden onset facial droop, with difficulty raising the eyebrow, inability to fully close the eye, or decreased tearing. The examiner should test the frontalis strength by asking the patient to wrinkle his forehead or raise his eyebrows. Orbicularis oculi strength is tested by asking the patient to close the eyes tightly while the examiner tries to open them. Procerus function is assessed by asking the patient to furrow the brow.        

Other historical and examination characteristics can help differentiate between the most likely cause of peripheral facial nerve palsy. Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can result in unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, may present with additional history of tingling or weakness in the extremities and with hypo- or areflexia on examination. Lyme disease can present with either unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy. Patients may report exposure to an endemic area, a tick bite, or a rash. The most common type of peripheral palsy, Bell palsy, is idiopathic, though some patients may report a recent illness or stressor. Exposure to keratitis can be treated with lubricating eye drops and patching. Treatment with oral corticosteroids within 72 hours of symptom onset is recommended, with improvement anticipated over the next three months.   

Option Analysis

✅ Lack of additional neurologic deficits :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hearing loss:
Incorrect: Herpes zoster oticus, also known as Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, can result in peripheral facial nerve palsy, with co-involvement of cranial nerve 8 given its proximity to the geniculate ganglion. Patients may describe ear pain, hearing loss, tinnitus, and dermatologic reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus with painful vesicles. This patient does not report ear pain, decreased hearing, or tinnitus and has no abnormal findings on ear exam, making Ramsay Hunt Syndrome unlikely. 
❌ Erythema migrans rash :
Incorrect: Lyme disease can cause central or peripheral facial nerve palsy in patients with a history of exposure to Lyme-endemic areas, a known tick bite, or a target-like rash, none of which are noted for this patient, making Lyme disease less likely.  
❌ Tingling in both feet and areflexia:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome can present with either unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, but typically patients will first notice ascending lower extremity numbness, weakness, or difficulty breathing; areflexia is another common finding. This patient has no symptoms or findings consistent with Guillain Barree syndrome.  
❌ Left arm numbness and weakness:
Incorrect: Ipsilateral numbness and weakness can be seen with central facial palsy, and in a patient with stroke risk factors it is suggestive of acute ischemia. This patient’s forehead involvement indicates the facial nerve palsy is peripheral and not central as would be expected with a stroke.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who is three weeks postpartum, presents to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness and difficulty breathing. Yesterday, her arm felt weak as she was brushing her hair, which she attributed to carrying her newborn baby. Today, she feels weaker and choked while eating breakfast and has had increased shortness of breath. She has a past medical history of asthma and uses albuterol as needed. She tried using her inhaler for the shortness of breath, but it failed to relieve her symptoms. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with ciprofloxacin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On exam, she has bilateral ptosis, and 4/5 strength with neck flexion and bilateral shoulder abduction. She has 5/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. Sensation and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with signs and symptoms of rapidly progressive painless weakness and respiratory distress in the setting of known precipitating factors (i.e., post-partum status and use of fluroquinolone) for myasthenic crisis. This patient has findings of impending respiratory failure from neuromuscular weakness. Her respiratory status should be emergently assessed with bedside pulmonary function testing, to determine the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.        

Some patients with myasthenia gravis may be present for the first time in crisis, precipitated by a weakened immune system, or from exposure to certain medications known to exacerbate myasthenia symptoms (e.g., fluoroquinolones). More often, patients with a known history of myasthenia gravis present with myasthenic crisis in the presence of precipitating factors.        

Patients with Myasthenic crisis present with respiratory distress with shallow respirations, tachypnea followed by bradypnea or hypopnea, and hypophonia, drooling, and dysarthria secondary to bulbar neuromuscular weakness. Use of accessory muscles for respiration or paradoxical breathing patterns may be noted. Hypercarbia and hypoxemia are late manifestations.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bedside pulmonary function testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Arterial blood gas (ABG):
Incorrect: An ABG will typically be normal in the initial stage in patients with symptoms of myasthenic crisis; hypercarbia and hypoxemia are late clues. If there is evidence of bulbar weakness and respiratory distress, bedside pulmonary function tests can guide intubation timing. 
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph will usually be normal in patients with respiratory distress from myasthenic crisis, though it may show diminished lung volumes from neuromuscular respiratory weakness. Immediate respiratory management should not be delayed for imaging. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) magnesium:
Incorrect: While IV magnesium is sometimes used in the treatment of status, this patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with myasthenic crisis. Her respiratory status should be assessed first with bedside PFTs to determine the need for intubation. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While IV corticosteroids are sometimes used in the treatment of status asthmaticus, this patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with myasthenic crisis, her respiratory status should be assessed first, to determine the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with generalized seropositive myasthenia gravis is admitted to the hospital for worsening weakness and difficulty swallowing. She has taken pyridostigmine daily for the past year and underwent a thymectomy six months ago. She started oral prednisone two weeks ago but has experienced hypertension, hyperglycemia, insomnia, and mood disturbance from the medication. She has a past medical history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 136/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis that worsens with sustained upward gaze. She is unable to keep her cheeks puffed against resistance, and there is weakness with shoulder abduction bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which additional treatment should be considered now?
questions.solution:
This 41-year-old woman presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, as evidenced by bulbar weakness, fatigable ptosis, and painless generalized weakness. She has worsening symptoms and may be experiencing a myasthenic crisis. When symptoms persist despite the use of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like pyridostigmine and oral immunosuppressants in combination with thymectomy, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasmapheresis should be considered.        

The most commonly used acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, pyridostigmine, can result in intolerable gastrointestinal side effects. Corticosteroids can lead to hypertension, hyperglycemia, fluid retention, bone loss, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Nonsteroidal immunosuppressant alternatives include azathioprine, mycophenolate, methotrexate, cyclosporine, cyclophosphamide, tacrolimus, and rituximab.        

In patients experiencing worsening symptoms and may be having an acute myasthenic crisis, IV corticosteroids can transiently worsen weakness. Other medications known to precipitate myasthenic crisis should be avoided in these patients too. These include beta blockers, magnesium, botulinum toxin, paralytics, and certain antibiotics.    

Option Analysis

✅ Plasmapheresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ High-dose intravenous (IV) corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient may be having a myasthenic crisis, and she has not been tolerating oral corticosteroids, therefore another mode of treatment should be used. Additionally, the use of high-dose IV corticosteroids may transiently worsen weakness in patients in myasthenic crisis.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) labetalol:
Incorrect: Although this patient has mild hypertension, it is likely a side effect of the oral steroids and should resolve with cessation of the medication. Furthermore, use of a beta blocker can exacerbate symptoms of myasthenia gravis, and they should be avoided. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) natalizumab:
